Food here was really good, had the Dan Dan noodles and black bean fish, highly recommended. Their cocktails were fairly expensive and it was served a cup that was filled with more ice than anything and very little alcohol content. Would discourage getting anything from their drink menu.

So happy to have found a tasty delivery spot after moving. The food was on time, hot, and delicious. It even passed the "left over test" the next day! High quality ingredients made for a great meal. Ordered Kung Pao Chicken (they said a 3 on spicy -- maybe more like a 4/5), Scallion Chicken (aka Mongolian chicken) and fried chicken dumplings.

Han Dynasty is a university city favorite. I come here almost every month since 2015- whether it be for big lab lunch meetings or dinner with family and friends. Han is a great go-to spot for a solid meal. 

You really can't go without getting the dan dan noodles. I usually do get it with the meat topping but my friend doesn't eat meat so there's none in my photos -still delicious. They give the spicy levels on the side in red but you can adjust them to any scale 0-10 since food is made to order. Stuff comes out very quick and rice sides are unlimited. 

My personal favorite is the black bean fish but I generally like everything they sell here. It's just that the service has been a bit lacking lately that the one star is taken off from this review.

A UCity staple! I've been here many times with friends to catch up over some great food and drinks. The service is hit or miss, sometimes you get someone who is very attentive and other times, you they only kind of visit you, but never bad. My go to order is the Dry Pepper Style fish or tofu and for the appetizer, the Dan Dan Noodles. What's great about this place is that you can adjust the spice level to you liking; they have a scale from 1-10, 10 being the hottest. The Dry Pepper Style is (8) and the Dan Dan Noodles come at a (6) [you can also get the meat on the side as we did!]. Every table gets unlimited rice, which the servers will refill as often as you need to, but only if your current rice bowl is empty. Also, a great beer that they serve here is Lucky Buddha, and it comes in a cute green, buddha shaped bottle, which we usually get but didn't this time.

Their food is pretty good, with notes of authentic Asian spices.  We had their fish and it was overdone with cornstarch to thicken the sauce.  That was definitely not our best choice.  Their steamed buns were pretty good, and their sichuan fries are some of the most authentic asian food I've had here in the states, despite being fries.
Food is ok. For university city may be it's the best choice for chinese foods. The choices are similar to food at home so very suitable for quick lunch or dinner
It's really good food but often the seating is too close to other tables. Like, I don't want to worry about bumping elbows with strangers while I eat dinner. You

I was here last summer with my two sisters and the food and service were outstanding. However, the last time I was here, which was a couple weeks ago, the experience was memorable but not because of the food. The food was once again delicious like last time. Some of the best asian food I've had. The service on the other hand was very unprofessional. I was with my mom and sister waiting for my other sister to arrive while the bus boy, I guess you would call him, tried to take our fourth place setting away, without asking if anyone else was joining us. We were still waiting on my other sister to arrive. When I told him this he rolled his eyes and said under his breath, "I guess she's invisible". I would have said something if my jaw wasn't on the floor and I also didn't want to have to worry about him spitting in my food. When the waiter came over he asked for our drink order and my mom told him what she wanted. He didn't even look up and then walked away! We had to flag him down to give us the other three drink orders! Every encounter from that moment on was so uncomfortable. He acted like he hated us and hated his life. Sorry buddy, but that's not our fault! He didn't seem to care how our food was either or if we needed more refills. He was honestly one of the most awkward and uncomfortable servers I've ever had and I felt like we were asking him for a favor when we finally got a hold of him. I know that some people are definitely more outgoing then others but if you're socially awkward you probably shouldn't be waiting tables! Next time I go here, it will be for take out!
Dry Pepper Chicken was good! Spicy level 6 was perfect. The fried chicken dumplings were a winner tho - would definitely get those again
Amazing food, friendly waiters, fast service, OOTW Drinks!!! First time here and it is awesome!!! Def coming back. So in love with the food

Hands down, this place has the best Chinese I've had in the Philly area! The food is spicy, but you know what you're getting based on the star levels. The kitchen forgot to make our fried rice during my last visit so it came out about 15 mins after the other dishes. The food was so tasty and fresh that we were still happy!

If you don't have hypertension, but want it, then this is your place. I will probably develop early onset hypertension after eating here. I keep hearing the hype for Han Dynasty, but it proved to be a let down. I will stick to Chinatown restaurants for Chinese food.

Ordered an appetizer, entree, and vegetable, and I'm convinced someone dumped a couple tablespoons of salt in each dish. Dish was remade, but still very salty. Service was not terrible, but not great. Would be nice if the hostess greets you and says, "one moment" instead of standing there and then walking off. I've never worked in customer service, but this seems like a no brainer. And we were also billed twice and needed it corrected... 

I actually visited a couple other times because I do believe in second chances. The food was better and service still not great. Dan Dan Noodles is pretty good, though I think the dish is better at the Manayunk location. I still wouldn't recommend Han Dynasty to anyone, but not completely opposed to going.

Tasty Dan Dan noodles. If you get take out, just toss them in a bowl to ensure the heat goes everywhere.
We also tried pork with pressed tofu and garlic style chicken. Both were flavorful with not too much oil. 
Pickup was quick (less than 20 minutes).

I hadn't been to Han's Dynasty in quite some time! I remember it being way to spicy for my taste at the time, but since then my spice tolerance has grown so much thanks to all the cool foodies I know who forced me to embrace the spice lol

I took the family here for Mother's Day because I knew everyone in that area of University city would be out of town, so the restaurant wouldn't be overly crowded or marking up the price that day.

We were told all the food is served family style so 3-4 dishes should feed 7-8 ppl which was pretty accurate. The host said rice comes out unlimited, but the only tedious thing was having to constantly ask for it instead of them bringing it out as we finished or just bring out one super huge bowl. We are professional rice eaters in my family, and I don't think Han Dynasty was prepared for that. 

We ordered the Scallion pancakes,Dan Dan Noodle,  Pepper Chicken , on Black Bean Style Fish, and one Garlic Tofu dish. All were solid, but the  Black Bean style fish was by far the best. The flavor was so sweet and spicy all at once and the fish was super moist. The cold Dan Dan noodles packed ALOT of spice and flavor as well. I wish I could take that sauce on the noodles home and pour it on everything...except cereal of course.

Anyway, the food was a home run here and the price point was way lower than we all expected. I can't wait to eat here again!

Yum! I loved this place. Quick service. Lots of options to personalize their dishes. Even though the garlic chicken had a spice level of three, they were able to make my dish not spicy for me. The chicken was flavorful and cooked perfectly. Not only was it delicious, but a great bang for your buck too. I definitely recommend stopping by and ordering off their lunch menu. They even offer bottomless rice with your meal!

Han Dynasty has come mighty far! From my first sight into the restaurant, I started counting the differences between this location and the Old City location.  The one familiarity, the deep savory smell of delicious Sichuan food a-cooking!

The ambiance is meant for University City - slick, young, and fast.  Modern Asian with generic attempts at urban edginess. Props to Han for the fire pit out in the seating area in front of the restaurant.  

The service was friendly but not the same type of server at the Old City location.  The waitstaff at this location proved to be a bit more green by forgetting two of our requests.  While they were upbeat and meant well, I was sorely disappointed by their lack of knowledge about the cuisine.  When asked why the dish was called "dry pot" style, the waiter responded "I really don't know, my best guess is because it has dry peppers and is made in a pot."  Even if that is the right answer, customers shouldn't receive a best guess.  Thus my docking the restaurant a point.  Even though Han has never been known for his bedside manner, he has always prioritized the food and his waitstaff should do the same.

The food is scrumptious and consistent with the other locations.  My recommendations are unfortunately generic - beef and tripe in chili oil and the dan dan noodles.  Stick with the authentic dishes and you can't go wrong.  I will say that I am not a fan of the americanized Chinese dishes, finding them too sweet.  As a whole, the food is a bit small portioned for its price.

Random thought - While the ornate metal tea pots are beautiful, I don't know that it is enough to compensate for how difficult they are to maneuver.

Finally got here a second time. It was delicious yet again. Garlic style beef, scallion style shrimp, hot pepper chicken, and house lo mein. I also ordered a cocktail (strawberry smash??? I think?). It was very good with fresh strawberries. It took a long time for them to just bring us our tea, but once they took our order everything was quick! So worth it. I can't wait until I have a chance to come back again !
To be honest the review is all hype this is probably the nastiest noodle u ever had super oily no flavor yuck

One of my reliable dining options in Philadelphia.  I only ordered takeout from the old city location and I couldn't stand the service of the Manayunk location.  University City was just right.

Not the best Sichuan ever, but best in Philadelphia.  Cumin chicken is a standout dish.  Tea smoked duck is fantastic.  Dan Dan Noodles are a subject of daydreams at work...

Service at this location is friendly and efficient.  Food comes out fast, but it's always busy there so the turnover keeps it fresh.  The portion sizes are huge so come hungry.  Additionally, they have some solid beers on tap.  Nothing like two pints of Dale 's Pale Ale on tap with your spicy Cumin Chicken.

Two issues that keep this place from finding hip, Chinese perfection:

1) consistency of spice level.  Sometimes my dishes would be burning and other days too pedestrian.  Don't understand the wild swings I experienced.

2) lots of hot oil.  The secret is oil.  Lots of oil.  Some dishes more than others, but it can be offputting for some.

There's only one way to describe Han Dynasty. F-ing awesome!!!! Lets start with the ambience, it's a casual sleek modern interior and there's a solid indie to classic rock playlist in the background. The service is amazing and fast. For starters the Dan Dan noodles are a must, but its fun to venture out and try some different stuff like szechaun pickled vegetables. 

For your main, it's family style but I often order one all to myself (especially at lunch when they have the incredible lunch special for 8.95!!!). I implore newbies to please be adventurous here. The first time I went I got some familiar kung pao...but after venturing out iv'e found out that ive been missing out on incredible szechaun cuisine my whole life. MUST TRY'S- the double cooked pork belly, it's honestly orgasmic, the dry fry beef, incredible. Any of the dry pot-especially pork is amazing.

If you ever run into their amazing and charismatic owner Han Chiang, then you're in for a real treat. Love this place have been going for two years, will continue to keep going.

My fiancee and I recently had Han Dynasty cater our engagement party. We couldn't have asked for a more positive experience. From the beginning, Nick, our point of contact, was extremely communicative and accommodating in helping create a menu for the party. We initially shopped around different restaurants due to my fiancee being vegan. Nick and the rest of the team at Han Dynasty were so quick to craft a vegan menu that was not only the perfect amount for the 50 people who attended the party, but delicious and extremely affordable. And they were BY FAR the quickest to respond and friendliest. Every single person at the party, vegan or not, could not stop talking about how delicious the food was. Nick arrived with the food at the location of the party at the exact time he said he would and helped set up quickly and then emailed us the next day to check in and make sure everything went smoothly, and even congratulated us on our engagement.

We are extremely grateful for Nick and the rest of the team at Han Dynasty and will recommend them for any future party and event. 
Thank you guys so much!

Moving in the middle of a pandemic isn't easy. After a long flight from across the country, being frustrated with TSA and people not knowing how to wear masks properly, I wanted something that was comforting and familiar. Luckily, Han Dynasty was close by and made me feel better after a long and arduous day. 

I had been here once before for a conference, but getting the experience living in the city is quite different. For now, it's either pick up or delivery, and it was nice to see that they were very cautious, and only allow people wearing masks to pick up food. I ordered some of the usual sichuan dishes, such as mapo tofu, water boiled beef, twice cooked pork, and string beans. After sampling almost every sichuan restaurant in my previous city of Houston, I can say that Han Dynasty can stand with the best. The mapo tofu has a wonderful texture, it wasn't broken up, and actually uses the right style of tofu. Water boiled beef had a great flavor, just enough sichuan peppercorn, and wasn't too greasy. The twice cooked pork was also really good, but it was half leeks and less meat than I would expect. String beans were cooked perfectly, just how I like it.

The price isn't terrible for the location, but it is more expensive than I am used to. Then again, I am new to the city so my needle has to probably change a bit. If you're already familiar with the dishes and are ordering online, it can be a bit confusing, since they go by "style". I would have also liked to have some more rice with my food. I ordered 4 dishes and only got 2 little to go containers of rice, which felt a bit skimpy.

Overall, this is going to probably be my new local. The flavor is great, resonably priced, and does an excellent job of protecting their customers and staff.

PS, if you haven't yet, the owner is featured on Munchies video by Vice.

The food is good and fresh. It's good service and a bunch of things you can try! Parking is available in the street. It's a nice clean restaurant with great prices. Yes I recommend yes I'll return! One of my favorite Asian spots to eat!
I waited over 40 minutes for a fried rice I ordered online 20 minutes before coming. A small fried rice. Needless to say they ruined date night. Thank you Han dynasty

Han Dynasty is a go-to for my family and I. My mother in law is pescetarian so this works great for all of us as there are so many different options for your protein. I love the dry fry style dishes, the wontons and dumplings in chili oil, and the scallion pancakes. My husband and the rest of my family love the dan dan noodles and they make excellent leftovers with an egg on top. I think I've been to all their Philly locations and highly recommend going!

1. A reliable friend
2. Savory and flavorful
3. Conducive to bonding

Consumed:
Dan dan noodles
Sesame noodles
Spicy crispy cucumber
Hot sauce style beef
Three cup chicken
Dry pepper fish
Double cooked chicken
Long hot pepper beef

I've checked in here literally 10 times and I'm embarassed to say I am now publishing this review. Part of the reason is because I've tried so many dishes here and I enjoy the food so much that words really don't do it justice. I highly just recommend visiting this u city restaurant ane finding out what I actually mean.

My favorite dish is the dry pepper fish! The texture is perfect and the flavor is just enticing. I only wish there was a bit more fish.

Highly dependent on what you order. Pork belly, Dan Dan noodles and most spicy stuff was good. Some other things were too breaded and greasy. Enjoyed it but it was hard on the stomach for a weekend brunch with all the oil.

So I have been to this restaurant multiple times and never really had a problem, food is always decent but slightly salty at times. However, today when I went for lunch we ordered our food and I asked for some of their spicy cucumber sauce on the side. After some time the waiter/bartender came back and said they need to charge me for the sauce. He said it'll be $1.00, which I was fine with. When we asked for our bill I saw they had charged me for an additional dish, Dan Dan noodles, and I asked and he was like that was for your sauce. Excuse me? If you were going to charge me $8.95 for a side of sauce than I would have ordered the actual appetizer for $6.95!!! I don't think that was right and feel really cheated! In the grand scheme of things it is only a few bucks but it's more about the principle and the fact that it wasn't fully related to me the actual price. I will have got think twice before I ever come back here again!

Dinner with the wife. 2 drinks, 3 apps, an entree, mid $50's, and left full and satisfied. Food comes out blazing hot. They cook it, put it at the window, and someone brings it to you in a matter of seconds. then you get to sit and look at it for a few minutes until it cools down to the point you don't burn your mouth off of your face. :-) food is delicious. They give you a heat scale from 1 to 10 where 10 is obviously the hottest. I love spicy food and even a six or seven has quite a bite. Free parking and easy parking on the street even on a Friday night at 7:30. Definitely recommend.

SO MUCH GOOD

The dry pepper chicken, at spice level 3,was perfect. It tastes a bit dry in comparison to the kung pao chicken at spice level 3. The kung pao chicken was perfectly seasoned and super duper moist. The cumin lamb was que delicioso as well. 

You should definitely order the "spicy" crispy cucumber appetizer. It isn't spicy and wasn't at all crispy, but my parents and I used this appetizer as a way to cool our palates in between tasting the different dishes, and to cool our tongues down just in case we bit into unsuspecting chilies.

Don't deprive yourself of those free refills of rice and tea. So basic yet fills out your meal awesomely.

Be careful if you have nut allergies- despite us explicitely telling our waiter that we didn't want nuts ( I forgot specifically which dish had it), the dish still came out with a few nuts in it.

I want to give this place 5 stars but I can't. They douse their food in chili oil and it's just too much. Even when I ask them for a spice level of 2 (you can request spice on a 1-10 scale, with 10 being hell and 1 being Netflix&Chill), it comes out as hot as a 6 or 7. Culinarily I don't think that makes one a good chef if you have to use so much oil for flavor. But that's just me. Having said that, there are so many good options here that are tasty and not spicy at all. The bok choy side dish is simple but so so good! The lo mein is cooked perfectly, the won ton soup is not too salty, and the dry fry style pork (as hot and spicy as it is!) is bite-after-bite crunchy perfection. If you do get the dry fry style pork, be aware that you will want extra rice to soak up some of the spice. 

The service is also just average. For a place that's supposed to be more upscale, I wasn't impressed. They don't check in on you enough and I found the hostesses at the front to be aloof and not friendly. It wasn't completely terrible which is why I've been back to dine here multiple times. My husband had his college graduation lunch here and they were able to accommodate his family; we were a party of 10. 

This is a great place to have a dinner date and it is definitely a step-up above most food in University City but I would say it is a bit over-hyped and overpriced.

Phenomenal service! Even when they are packed, you get served in no time. As you will probably see throughout all of these reviews, the spicy cucumbers and dandan noodles are an absolute must! Also try the the thinly sliced pork belly in garlic chili oil appetizer -- it might look daunting covered in red oil, but it is addictive. 

On Valentine's Day we got the "double dragon", which is two lobsters on a bed of spaghetti-like noodles and greens. The way they prepared the lobsters really made eating it not a hassle at all. Reserve a table beforehand if you want to go here on an occasion like v-day.

Han dynasty is a fine dining restaurant where you know you can't go wrong with the experience. So on one undecided Saturday afternoon we decided to have lunch at their university city location. Seated promptly and we were given waters. Shortly our server came over and asked if we had a chance to look over the menu. We wanted to get a bottle of Prosecco, so we ordered the same and explored the menu. The server came with an open bottle of Rose', my SO pointed this out to him and he apologized and this time brought the unopened bottle of Prosecco and had us check. He poured the flutes and dropped some, used my napkin to wipe and said I will get you another. (He was probably new so we didn't mind). 
We proceeded to order the food and decided on getting 2 apps and 2 entrees. 
We had just about finished 2 sips of the Prosecco when our entree's were placed on the table. We were both looking at each other like- what? We asked another server to cancel the appetizer since what's the point ? He apologized and walked over to the kitchen, care back and said the apps are ready. At this point our experience was kinda ruined and we just wanted to finish the meal and get out of there. Which is unfortunate because the food is bloody delicious! 
5/5 for the food - scallion pancakes, spring rolls, lo mein and dry hot pot style chicken. 
They seriously need to up their service !

After coming to this location multiple times and the location in manayunk, I have to say the food is consistent in quality. Large portions at relatively cheap prices. Cucumbers in chili oil, dan dan noodles, sesame noodles, beef tendons in chili oil, and double cooked pork belly are all winners in my book. And the University city location offers a decent beer selection. Def a plus.

3.0/5

Not sure why this place is so popular. I thought the food was really oily, and tasted like your standard Americanized Chinese food -- maybe just a few notches above Panda Express. Of course, Panda Express / Chinese takeout does hit a certain sweet spot, so if that's what you're looking for, then by all means come here. If you're looking for authentic Chinese food however, I don't think this is the place for you.

We tried to place an order and were quite surprised by the total. The prices on the menu were not what they charged us and when we asked why they had no explanation. We asked them to honor the prices on their site and could provide snapshots of the online prices the person working said he couldn't make any adjustments and he would "alert Managment" about the discrepancy. 

We asked if there was anything that could be done and he said want moved or interested in finding a solution. We ended up canceling our order and he mumbled something as he hung up the phone. 

The price discrepancy was apparently across every item. A total bill went from $49.35 to over $62 before tax.

This is a great example of a business that is uninterested in serving the customer or rectifying their own mistake. They seem ok losing business due to inconsistency or concern for customer satisfaction.

We worked with Megan to organize a work happy hour event at Han Dynasty for about 60 people. We were planning the even remotely from San Francisco, but Megan was so responsive and took the time to send us pictures and explain the space to us (we had the semi-separated area in the back of the restaurant - it was a great space for our group with plenty of sitting/standing room). 

The staff during our event was so wonderful and patient and were able to handle all of our drink orders smoothly. The food Megan helped us pick up was SO GOOD, and was very reasonable for the amount of food and people we had. Thank you Han Dynasty for a great work event!

i came in with super high expectations (years of hearing word-of-mouth buzz on how awesome han dynasty is will do that to you) and our meal pretty much surpassed all of them. the wontons in chili oil and the cold sesame noodles were probably my favorite orders of the night, but everything else (eggplant with garlic sauce, dan dan noodles, and dry pot style lamb) was seriously delicious too - and spicy!

Biggest grievance about this place is how they categorize their spiciness. I think they had a white guy from Minnesota do it (cue hate mail from white people/ Minnesotans). Buuuuut I get it. It's really freakin' hard to judge the levels. Because there's my Indian friend who's laughing at the 8 spicy level and then there's my mixed European friend who's dying at spice level 3. So I get it. 

After much spice calibration, I have a fondness for this place. I may be the only person alive who doesn't pine for the dan dan noodles or the spicy crispy cucumbers (both tasty items, but not reason why I crave the place). I think their strongest suit is their tasting menu. You can "choose your adventure" i.e. be adventurous or not, and you can get it for as low as $20 per person. The pricier it gets per person, the more fun food you get. And you can specify things like spice level, or mostly seafood, or please no tripe etc etc. Which I think is a lot of fun. They only do it for groups though, but it's fun on someone's birthday to know what the flat price everybody is paying and then just share everything. Love it!

I ordered take out just as they were closing and was on my way to pick up the food on my bike when it started to downpour one night. I got drenched and had to turn back around. I asked if they could refund the order or honor it on another day because it had only been 10 minutes since I put in the order and they refused to do the refund or consider my suggestion. The worst part was the ASSHOLE on the phone called me lazy for not wanting to pick up the food and said that if other customers could pick up their food I was just choosing not to get mine. I had no other means of getting the food in the weather conditions and instead of being sympathetic this guy kept insulting me. I will never eat at this dump again I've never met a more condescending person in customer service.

Would not recommend ordering Takeout/delivery here! We just placed an order via Door Dash , where we specifically wrote "mild spicy", but all dishes that came are super duper spicy. Their chefs don't read the instructions here for takeout/delivery, and I was very disappointed because my dine-in experiences were much different.

This is generally regarded as the best Chinese food restaurant around UCity focusing specifically on Szechuan / Sichuan cuisine. I took my family there when they visited me in college, and they said this is one of the best Chinese food restaurants they had and the food tasted even better than the ones we cook at home, which is a huge compliment. I think if you like a good amount of spice, but there are also lots of non-spicy options. The service is really fast, and you get seated pretty quickly as people shuffle in and out. All and all definitely a solid, can not go wrong option, but I don't think it's outer worldly good. Most people recommend the dan dan noodles - I think it's okayish good, I personally think the eggplant and string beans are both good veggie dishes.

Han Dynasty used to be one of my favorite restaurants. I have been going there since they first started in Old City and only had one location. The food was always good and consistent, although a little pricey for Asian food. It was one of the very first to introduce and popularize szechuan-style food to the Philadelphia area. However, in recent years and on my most recent visit to their University City location, I'm not sure that I will continue to be a regular. 

I am not sure if it was the particular chef at this location, if they have Americanized their dishes, or simply changed the recipes, but I no longer enjoy the many dishes I used to love. The Dan Dan Noodles, Spicy Crispy Cucumber, and the Tea Smoked in Beer Sauce taste very different. The noodles and the cucumbers are much more sweet than before. I find that although they are still spicy, the sweetness overpowered any spiciness in the dish. It was still good, but as far as authenticity and overall taste, it was not what it used to be. 

Additionally, the smoked duck WAS ALL BONES! There never was that much meat on the duck itself, but this time it seemed like they tore off all the meat on the duck and used it for another dish and gave us the leftovers. For $18.95, this is a rip-off. The flavor is good, but not enough to compensate because the rest of the dish is just filler ingredients. 

The cucumber used to be coated and soaked in chili oil, but now it is in a creamy, spicy/sweet sauce. The taste is weird and strange. 

I might give it another chance, at least at the Old City location, but is it one of my favorites still, not really.

It was good, we were there right before they closed and they were accommodating without appearing annoyed(I work in restaurants I know how it goes lol). Vibe was chill, nothing too crazy, food was cool.  I ain't writing home about it but I'd definitely go back.

What a refreshing find, a restaurant outside of Chinatown with authentic chinese cuisine catering to a non-chinese crowd! No sesame chicken here! This place is Szechuan style, meaning the food is SPICY. For the non-masochists out there, their non-spicy plates are delicious too! Our party of 20 came for a $25/person tasting menu on a busy Saturday night which consisted of numerous dishes. I eventually lost count as the plates streamed to our table and were passed around for everyone to share. There was plenty of food for everyone to have a good portion.

For appetizers, I remember the Pork Belly, Scallion Pancakes, Wontons in Chili Oil, Dan Dan Noodles, and Cold Sesame Noodles. The scallion pancakes and noodle dishes remind me of home - just like how mom makes them. The other appetizers are pretty spicy, and they are great if you can handle the heat.

For entrees, I remember the Black Bean Style Beef, Dry Fry Style Pork, and Double Cooked Style Fish. Black Bean Style Beef reminded me of "Pepper Steak & Onion" which is an order at a typical chinese-american take out places, but the black bean sauce at Han Dynasty is far better than the sauce from a take out place. Not a spicy dish at all. The Dry Fry Style Pork consists of shredded pork and tons of sichuan peppercorns which leave your tongue numb. The Double Cooked Fish is a fried fish, not very spicy and delicious. Entrees are served with plenty of white rice in a futile attempt to help soothe your burning tongue.

Service needs improvement though. Our waitress was around, but she just kind of had a non-chalant personality. She didn't put much effort into explaining the tasting menu. We also waited an hour before we got our appetizers. Then we waited another hour before we got our entrees. It was a busy night, and there were several other parties doing the tasting menu, but an hour wait between food seems a bit excessive. I would expect bad service from a place in Chinatown, but I had much higher expectations for service from Han Dynasty in Old City. 

Besides the service, the only other thing that could have improved our experience is if we had a round table large enough for our entire party and a lazy susan to spin our food around (which is a sign of a true authentic Chinese restaurant).

OVERALL: Despite the bad service, Han Dynasty is getting four stars for great value - good prices for quality and quantity of food.

I met Han on the first day he opened his first restaurant in Exton some 6-7 years ago. Since then I am glad to see his restaurant empire grow and am a weekly (sometimes multiple times a week) customer.

Though I usually visit the suburb Han Dynasty's, I can honestly say this locations is one of the best with its distinctive Cumin Lamb, Dan Dan noodles and a dish which is not that well known but the best on the menu....drum roll please....fish with hot dry peppers.

Also remember to get the Cold chicken in chili oil, spicy cucumbers and Taiwanese sausage as appetizers. The West Lake soup is good but I usually skip it unless there are people in our dining group who do not like hot food (a rarity). Three cup chicken usually satisfies the people who like mild food.

Check out the great drink specials and beers on tap.

I've been here several times over the years. It's pretty consistent and if you know anything about Han Dynasty, you're coming for the heat. This place also has a decent cocktail list. They close at 10 on weeknights, but if you come anywhere close to that (we arrived at 930), be prepared to be rushed out and reminded a few times that the kitchen closes at 10. I get the "end of the night" feeling as an eating establishment with staff that wants to go home (I remember my days of working in a restaurant and hoping the place is empty by closing) but it is a bit unnerving when the order is put in a half hour before the kitchen closes and it feels like you just ruined the lives of everyone that has to serve you food. It might have been because we were end -of -the -evening customers, with end -of -the -evening -food, but while the flavor and heat on my dry pepper fish was good there were more than a few pieces that were inedible. I'm not sure if they were fried too hard or were the bony tail of the fish but I couldn't even chew through them. I pushed them to the side of my plate and kept it rolling. Our server himself, was gracious and quick with a smile, which was refreshing. I don't regret stopping through. I will just make sure the next time I visit I am on the early side of the evening so I don't get the side-eye.

I so miss this Han Dynasty. When i lived in west Philly I had their spicy noodles 2x a week. Soo good. I miss them so much I may have to roll over the river to get an order since the Old City location is, in my opinion, subpar. 

Im coming for you Handy Nasty for your hot noodles that make my taste buds so happy.

I really think people who post Negative reviews about this establishment are looking for a free meal in the future from Han...

Ok with that out the way I will begin my review..
The atmosphere is great and the staff is very attentive to your needs when either getting a refill on drinks or more food. The manager ( Jermaine ) is very professional and aware of the needs of his customers.  The wait staff and kitchen is very quick with getting your order to your table.

I first started coming to sit at the bar and watch football games and now that they have opened up the other side with more screens and a sitting area for watching sports it is very much a spot to hang out and enjoy food while enjoying your favorite team. 

I have recommended this place to plenty and have had birthday parties and football parties here..
The drinks are great, the food is great and the staff is awesome..
if you sit at the bar and get to meet either C.J , or Maria , or Najia then your in good hands and the waitress Bo is always friendly and the Manager Jermaine will always come around to check on his customers...
This is a sign of a true restaurant that is aware of the economy and what it takes to stay open. with all the other choices for places to eat in the area the quality hasn't changed since they have opened.. 

Dan Dan Noodles , Garlic Chicken are my favorite

Let me begin by stating that I'm very skeptical of 'chain' restaurants serving anything but sandwiches/salads/soups but I was pleasantly surprised when my husband got me to try Han Dynasty. After my first visit I quickly became a fan! They have flavorful food that you can customize to your level of 'spice comfort' and generous portion sizes that can easily be split between 4 people. I have been to both the U City and Old City locations -- food was equally good at both. Whenever I have family/friends visiting they are always asking about this place and I find myself always going back. Plan to call ahead of time to avoid the wait because this place is popular!

Overall really enjoyed my dinner here! We had mapo tofu, dumplings, and rice. The dumplings were good, but not as good as others I've had.They were wrapped in a thicker dough than I'm used to, which was overwhelming with the pork. The mapo tofu was tasty! Service was quick, overall. Definitely would return.

This is one of my favorite places to go to. I met this one busser that goes by the name Randy and he already makes me want to come back. I have never seen anyone cleaned tables as well as he can. he goes back and forth with a firm and strong grip, i was so amazed. my jaws literally dropped. And not only that but his abilities to hand out food was astounding. perfect balance and a soft touch. To top it all of is that perfect smile of his. I wish i knew his work schedule so i can visit him everyday and watch him clean tables. i wish he could clean my tables at home too.

i used to work only a few blocks away from here, which made it incredibly easy to stop by for lunch. those were the days... i've tried a little bit of everything on the menu by this point, even though i still rely on my two favorites - chicken with garlic sauce and dan dan noodles.

other good picks include: 
- wontons in chili oil
- cold sesame noodles
- eggplant with garlic sauce
- dry pot style lamb
- hot sauce style fish (completely boneless, if you were wondering)
- cumin style chicken (warning! this will make you smell like cumin for the rest of the day, so don't eat it for lunch if you're going back to the office because everyone will avoid you)
- salt and pepper style shrimp
- crispy rice style chicken (very mild and a little sweet, which is the complete opposite from the rest of the menu)
- scallion style chicken (also on the milder side)

First time at this location for Han Dynasty. It's a nice big restaurant. We came around lunch time and the food came out super fast and super hot. I got the dry pepper chicken and dan dan noodles. The chicken I got seemed to be over cooked/fried with the breading extra crispy. I don't necessarily enjoy it that way, but it was still good. The noodles were great. We weren't greeted in the most pleasant way by the hostess, but our waiter took good care of us. Fair warning - great food, but you'll take the smell wit you for the rest of the day on your clothes, lol.

OH MY LAWD. THIS PLACE WAS SO DELICIOUS. After being worried when seeing the spice levels listed on the menu, I found I can even do a level 9! I tried a lot of different items from garlic chicken, to dry pot tofu, to pork belly! Everything was delicious from the tea, to the entrees. In my opinion it's best to go with a larger group of people so you can do the family style dining!

So happy Han Dynasty is delivering during the quarantine - we order from them on a regular basis - the dry pepper chicken was cooked to perfection with the perfect crunch and heat - I call it crack chicken because it's that good! Add fried rice, dumplings in chili oil and you're golden.

yep, the Dan Dan. everything else i've had was hella good too, except for the sort of pickledy tofu item (you'll see it i think, if you're looking). additionally, Han is a cool, real person. we hung out for a while on a rare slow night over there, and i had an awesome time and i think he and my friend did too. i intend to go back over there again soon, not just for the nosh but for the spirit of the joint too. 

namaste.

-nda
Dan Dan noodles are th only thing I've eaten here. Most of it is out of my price range but those noodles are cheap and amazing.
ok food.. I had better in center city..

I am so glad this placed opened up in University City. I've been to the Old City location a couple times and have always been pretty satisfied with the food. No longer am I forced to go to Sang kee, Won Oriental or Beijing if I craved Chinese food and was too lazy to go far from University City. The interior of this one is a lot better, it is more spacious, and you can opt for outdoor seating as well.

I would recommend getting the braised beef noodle soup, Taiwanese fried rice and chinese cabbage were all delicious and remind me of home. Other dishes I am planning to try are chicken in chili oil, hot sauce style fish and  the cumin lamb. I had tried them in the Old City location, and they were pretty tasty. I don't see it being any different here. I would probably steer away from the scallion pancake and dumplings here if you were looking for something super authentic. The scallion pancake didn't have the right texture and flavor. The dumplings were also a little doughy - too thick for my liking. 

Also, if you are worried that you can't handle the spice, you can always ask them to make it less spicy.My friend who doesn't eat any spicy food at all have no problem finding food she likes here (Taiwanese sausage fried rice and beef noodle soup).  I usually make the dan dan noodles non-spicy or else it's too much for me to handle as well. 

I will definitely be frequenting here!!! Good bye Sang Kee, Won oriental and Beijing!

I've been a long-time fan of Han Dynasty's Royersford branch (try the authentic wonton soup!), so I went into the University City locations with high hopes. It did not disappoint. The decor is modern and attractive and the staff friendly and, well, also attractive but that's neither here nor there.

As for the food, I had the pork belly - a safe bet to be sure, but I was duly impressed. Each bite had a nice combination of meat and succulent fat, and the very spicy, slightly sweet sauce was delicious. Also of note, and somewhat unique for a Chinese restaurant, were the craft beers on tap, even some I'd never seen before, which as a beer geek I always appreciate. If you're in the city and looking for Chinese food that's high-quality without being exorbitantly  priced, I highly recommend Han Dynasty.

i love Han Dynasty! It's really great for large groups because you can order many dishes family size and all the dishes are delicious!!! 
pros: 
-i love the dry pepper style fish. It is so crispy and crunchy, but the fish inside is so soft and tender. it's not too overpowering but the chilis add a nice kick. make sure not to eat the chili peppers though, v spicy LOL 
-the green beans are so good!!! theyre not soggy or not too crunchy. 

Cons: 
-the honey walnut shrimp was pretty expensive with not too many pieces , and a bit too creamy for me. I think some of the dishes are pretty expensive but the portions are very small compared to the price 
-service was a bit slow. It makes sense because there are a lot of people at the restaurant, but we would ask for more water or rice and it would take some time

Ordered a take out! So this review is only based on price and food and the take out experience. 

We ordered the homemade style tofu and dry pepper chicken. The dry pepper chicken is shooo goodd with lots of msg which we all love, right?  
The portion of the rice was generous. I do have to wait for a while for the food to arrive, around 1.5 hours (I live not too far away). Will try the dine in experience next time. Recommended!

Delicious menu with tons of great options and very reasonable prices. A perfect place for lunch or dinner with friends! They also do a great job with takeout which offers very generous portions. I'd like to see a few more health options, but overall a very solid restaurant

I decided to come here for a birthday dinner with friends. We were a party of 12. Even though we had a large group the service was amazing. Our server made sure to accommodate any allergies and as many food preferences as he could. The food was amaze balls!! We went with the $25 per person tasting menu. We had so many wonderful dishes. I think my favorite however were the cold sesame noodles and the beef. The noodles were so great with the best tasting sauce and the right amount of seasoning ohh I want some now while writing this review. With the tasting menu you get to try a little bit of everything. The more you are willing to pay the more exotic the foods get. You can expect to see seafood and chef specials. The only downfall is that you can only use two credit cards per a table so make sure everyone brings cash if in a large group. Also take into account taxes and the added gratuity. Each person paid about $34 for their meal which is kind of pricey but for good quality food it is worth it!!
Han is definitely one of my favorite Chinese places to go. Their food is really authentic and hot.. So are some of the bartenders & waiters. (Another reason why I enjoy going there!).
I go here because they offer gf soy sauce. The food is good but can be way too spicy at times so you really have to specify your preference!

Super convenient for Chinese food not in Chinatown! 

Beef Lo Mein was delicious. Not super salty like most take out restaurants. I also enjoyed the Sichuan spicy beef noodle soup. They separate the soup and noodles for take out. The noodles are thick which I prefer. The soup was on the oily side. I also tried the dry pot style chicken. Chicken was tender and the flavor was yummy.  That dish was my favorite!

I realize during COVID they're doing the best they can but I was really upset with the food I got at han dynasty. My sister was visiting and I had really high hopes of her trying Szechuan food and especially their Dan dan noodles because they're known for it, but was very disappointed. They said to come in 15-20 minutes and i came about 17 minutes later and they had it ready so no complaints there, but the noodles themselves tasted as if they had been sitting in the sauce for over a day because they were very soggy and didn't taste good. And because they were soggy they clumped together making the meal pretty gross. We also got cold sesame noodle which also wasn't good, it became a warm sesame noodle by the time we got it. They must've just let the food sit there or something. Maybe this isn't one of those places that's good for take out and better enjoyed in person

One of the better Chinese spots near Penn's campus - if a group of friends is looking for somewhere nicer to eat or if my family's visiting, I like to take them here! The interior is nice and spacious, and there's a modern vibe to the place. 

Recs:
- Dishes: Dan Dan noodles - one of the best in my opinion, Fish in spicy oil (shui zhu yu)
- Get the lunch special - it's a smaller portion than a normal entree but a great size for a portion at lunch!

I don't know how to begin a review of this place. It is the single best Chinese food restaurant I've ever been to, soaring high above others in Philly and on the Main Line, which I have rated highly as well. The food, the service, the speed, the drinks, the food again!

Everything about the Han Dynasty experience screamed 5 stars for me. First, the staff here needs to be commended or awarded with some kind of prize, collectively or as individuals. The service here is really beyond anything I would ever expect at any restaurant. Not only are they constantly filling my water glass and refreshing my cocktail, they are right on the money with recommendations and the food comes out at lightning speed. Extra props to the kitchen on that one too! 

When the food comes out like a bullet from a gun, it is not only piping hot, but unearthly delicious. The Dan Dan Noodles, Szechuan fries, Chili Dumplings, Dry Pepper shrimp, Crispy Rice with Chicken, Tofu Hot Pot, the list goes on and on.  The spice designations are a fun and helpful way to navigate the menu, though it should be known you can adjust the spice level on any dish to suit your tastes. We take most everything down to a 4, though I think we've gone as high as a 7! The best part is no matter how spicy something is here, the flavor comes through and wins the day.

I have never gotten something I didn't love at Han Dynasty. And I've always left with food to eat later. Most of it I've eaten that very night while standing in front of the fridge. Give it a try. And then another try later that night standing in front of your fridge. You will be in love.

Have stopped by for dinner on two occasions several months apart while visiting a student at UPenn. The Dan Dan noddles are a definite must-have (get them spicy if you can). Comfortable but sleek ambience, friendly service, great food. The restaurant definitely has western influences, most notably in the environment and decor, but the food was fairly authentic. Would recommend coming with a small group.

Rating based on solely food (not service)

Great Szechuan food in the west philadelphia (university city) location.  And they adjust the level of spicy per request.

Spicy Crispy Cucumber - it was spicy, crispy.  It was was what you expect.

Cold Sesame Noodle - a very close alternative from the Dan Dan noodles.  The sauce was little more thicker than the Dan Dan but very similar

Double cooked fish ($17.95) - one of the best things on their menu.  Crispy and meaty fish.  However this is a bit on the expensive side.

Mapo Tofu ($11.95) - portion size was great.

Brown rice - there's an upgrade charge for brown rice.

This place is great for parties more than 2 so that you can order many things to share.  If you have a party of 2, 2 dishes and a bowl of rice will be enough!

The food is awesome. Alway fresh and you can tell it was cooked to order and not just stuff made in bulk and served to you. It's not greasy and they do a great job with the spice levels. My go-to is the scallion chicken that comes with white rice, and veggie lo mein because I hate white rice lol. The portion sizes are pretty good. With those two dishes (minus the rice) I can get 2-3 servings out of them so it's worth the money. Delivery is always well prepared and packaged, always arrived hot or at least warm enough to eat right out the container without reheating. No leaks or spills and they send reusable containers which is great. Save the planet! They are my go-to Chinese spot whenever I have a craving. 9/10 would recommend.

Han Dynasty definitely secured its throne as one of the best, if not the best, Szechuan restaurants in Philadelphia. The dishes and flavors are consistent within and across locations. 

Today I ordered an app and two entrees: Spicy Crispy Cucumber, Dry Pepper Fish, and Double Cooked Chicken. The cucumbers are a great starter - super refreshing and crunchy, low heat, and delightfully sweet. I would eat bowls and bowls of rice with the sauce they prepare with the cucumbers - it's THAT good!

I like to experiment with different combinations of styles and proteins each time I visit Han Dynasty. The fish was superb - the fish were both seasoned well and the batter was super crunchy. I felt the spicy rating of an 8 for dry pepper was a bit high for this dish, the fish was more mild in spice. The chicken was super tender and moist (white meat) and I really enjoyed the almost sour and spicy flavor profile of the double cooked style. 

The service was very attentive and friendly making sure that we were getting our food promptly and very apologetic when the orders were being held back. We had to wait a tad bit longer for our second entree, which was my only criticism. Otherwise, Han Dynasty is still a fav in my book (and stomach)!.

Ordered take out from Han Dynasty. I have tried both the praises Dan Dan noodles and lo mein... and for me lo mein is the winner! Absolutely delicious noodles! Additionally, their spring rolls are some of the best I have ever eaten! Prices are reasonable when the plates are shared
Good tasting Asian food with a standard variety of menu options. Prices are reasonable and the location has ample seating.

Yelped Chinese food when the family and I were in town and this is the best we found. We were all a bit disappointed but it did the trick, I guess. The service was good though, it was just that none of us were really a fan of the food.
Spicy crispy cucumber appetizer: this was probably one of the best things we had. It was refreshing and had a nice kick to it. 
Dan dan noodles: did not like this at all. The noodles were cooked right and probably would have been good had it not been for them dumping what tasted like an entire jar of peanut butter over them. The first bite was okay but no one was able to eat more than a couple bites of them. Seriously guys, ease up on the peanut sauce (aka Jif peanut butter).
Schezwan curry chicken: not bad
Chicken dry pot: I actually liked this one. It was very spicy and the chicken in it was very tender. I just wish it had more chicken in it.
Between 4 of us we would usually easily finish the amount of food we ordered but there was plenty of leftovers. That says something about everyone's thoughts on the food. Sorry guys, just being honest

Good prices, good food. The dan dan noodles were good. Three cup chicken was hot and savory. Cumin lamb was amazing. The only thing I didn't like was the dumplings in chili oil, but that was only cause it paled in comparison to everything else.

Ok, so years back, they actually served spicy food here. One of the best dishes I've had at Han Dynasty was something another person in my party ordered and then couldn't actually eat due to the spice. It was, indeed, very very spicy and also very, very delicious.

More recently though, the spice levels went down... by a lot. Last time I visited, I ordered a Dry Pepper Style entrée that's listed as an 8/10 on the spice scale, and found that it was barely spicy. Tonight, I ordered a Dry Pot Style entrée--supposedly a 10--and it was, to me, at most *mildly* hot.

My friends disagreed with my assessment that the food was not spicy, but they didn't think it was searingly hot either. And everything we ordered was 7-10 so it really should have been. And look, ok, I suppose I do have a pretty high spice tolerance but I've had food here that I'd consider hot--just years and years ago. Based on my more recent experiences I can't imagine anyone other than my very Eastern European grandmother being unable to eat the level 10 dishes.

If we could award half-stars I'd give the place 3.5, because heat level aside, it was an enjoyable meal. The service was just ok--not very attentive considering it was a quiet night. But the food was tasty and the sauces were very nice. Still, if I wanted a mild, enjoyable meal, I could get that almost anywhere.

Pretty quick and very friendly service + delicious food! My waitress was really nice and gave great recommendations.
I ordered dumplings in chili oil and Dan Dan noodles, and I like how I was able to customize the spiciness level of my food. So so so good, but do not underestimate the spiciness of the food here!!! Really appreciate that they also mixed my noodles for me when they brought the dish to the table.
I also enjoyed receiving complimentary hot tea before my meal. Overall, great experience.

One thing to mention, I noticed on their menu that they automatically add gratuity to parties of 6+ and take up to 3 cards per party. Just a heads up in case you're planning on coming here with a large group of people!

This is the first time I was at this Han Dynasty.  I usually find myself in either the Exton (flagship) or Cherry Hill locations.   It is interesting how each location has its own vibe and variation in food preparation.  I like all of their locations.

We always order the DanDan noodles no matter which one we go to.  This was slightly disappointing on this visit.   It came out first and right away.  Unfortunately, it was tepid at best, like it was intended for another table (since our server told us our dumplings would come out first followed by everything else).

The wontons in hot chili oil also had a garlic paste at the bottom.  It was good but it is the first time we had them like that.   A bit extra heat.

Kung pao chicken is the standard order for one of us and it was not particularly spicy even though it rated a spice level of 3.

The three cup chicken, a standard for my other dining partner, was excellent here as as well.   

I enjoyed the shredded pork with pressed tofu.   However, after eating such hot appetizers, this seemed too bland.   My leftovers tasted better the next day.

Service was good but servers were stingy on the rice as we had to ask for extra more than once.

I ordered the crispy rice style with chicken. Most of the ingredients were not fresh. The button mushrooms, water chestnuts, and bamboo shoots were all from a can. The sauce tasted like it was from a bottle. The chicken was good. There was way too much sauce, and the sauce was grossly thick. The crispy rice was also disappointing. It was actually rice cakes (like the ones you get from the store and put peanut butter on). It didn't go well with the dish at all. I ended up having to get plain rice. For $15, I do not recommend. I was bamboozled. The food gets 1 star, the service gets 5, and that's why I gave 3.
So good. Unlike any other Chinese food I've ever eaten. It's spicy, flavorful and fresh.
I haven't experienced them since covid begun, but the food is good, kinda pricey but good. Food is always in good time, and design of the place is really cool.
LOVE the food here! Everything we get is always spot on! From the lo mein to the spicy cucumbers to the dumplings! I recommend this place 100%

Han Dynasty is always good when I can dine in, the food is flavorful and hot and tasty. I recently ordered takeout and got the dan dan noodles, home style tofu and scallion pancakes. The scallion pancakes were great once toasted as they don't retain the heat from delivery. Loved the home style tofu, a great option for vegetarians and it comes with generous amounts of the fried tofu that is steaming with heat and flavor. The dan dan noodles are average--it's better to remix it when you get it as the sauce tends to sink to the bottom. Han didn't give any chili oil for the noodles, but I find that the noodles are much better with a bit of chili oil and vinegar. Another dish that I love is the garlic style tofu, which is pressed tofu in garlic sauce with veggies. Overall, Han Dynasty is a solid restaurant and the portions are large!

Tonight was my second visit to this particular Han Dynasty. The actual restaurant is styled very nicely and its a pleasant dining experience. We sat outside last time and tonight we sat inside, right next to the bar. The bar is beautiful and well stocked. The tea is a nice touch and both times my boyfriend and I stayed after paying just to enjoy the tea. The servers were very attentive and often checked in on and refilled water classes whenever we were running low, which is something that a lot of servers seem to overlook. 

On our first visit, we ordered the chicken lo mein and the dry pot style chicken. Both were ordered at a spice level of 10, although we suspect that our waiter put them at a lower spice level because we ended up having to ask for extra chilli oil. Aside from the spiciness, however, both the noodles and the chicken were great. There were a lot of bugs and mosquitos around (we sat outside) and I was paranoid about one of them landing in the food so instead of eating seconds, we just took the rest to go. Needless to say, the food was quickly eaten later than night..

This time around, we got an all vegetarian meal. We ordered the vegetable fried dumplings, the vegetable lo mein, and the garlic sauce style tofu all at a spice level of 10, once again. The dumplings were yummy and we both ate three quite quickly. But the noodles and the tofu- phew. This time, for whatever reason, the spice level was MUCH more intense than the last. It was definitely spicy! I, personally, loved it because the spicier the better, but my poor boyfriend couldn't get past a couple bites (even though he can eat very spicy food, usually). My advice would def be to pay attention to the spice levels- a ten is definitely a ten... or at least it was this time around. lol 

It is a bit more pricey for chinese but honestly, this is the only chinese place in university city that I actually can see myself craving so I guess its just something that I'll have to deal with. (As a price reference, the three things we got tonight ended up costing around 32 bucks.)

Over all, a solid four star place that you should check out if you want spicy chinese thats much, much better than any other chinese place in University City.

It gets a 5, if you are looking for a excellent Chinese meal on the hotter side. Yet if spicy chinese food is not your thing, then try somewhere else. Almost a wait line every night even with their huge interior dinner sections and outdoor patio.Says something about its popularity.

The Dandan noodle, cucumber salad and double cooked fish are some of my favs.

As a sidenote, the food during lunch might not have equal quality during dinner time.

If you want to get a taste of Sichuan cuisine, Han Dynasty is definitely a great spot to experience it. It is one of our go-to places in University city with friends or family for a chill night. The service is super quick and you will receive your food steaming hot and fresh!!! We ordered Dan-Dan Noodles (pic attached), Garlic Sauce Style Chicken (pic attached) and Dumplings in Chilli Oil. They also offer delivery service, which we have been taking full advantage of during Covid season.

I had a professional meetup at Han Dynasty- Univeristy City. We were a group of 11 people, and we met at noon on a Saturday. Our table was ready for us when we showed up. We sat on one of the round tables in the back. The table was big but we could still hear each other especially that the music was low so that was definitely a plus! We didn't really do the family style ordering because so many of us but I still had the chance to taste the following: spring rolls, beef Lo Mein, chicken crispy rice style, tofu dry pepper style. Everything was great! My favorite was the beef Lo mein- so good! The waitress was very attentive as well.

Han Dynasty is my go-to Chinese restaurant in the University City neighborhood. My boyfriend and I love the dry pepper chicken, dan dan noodle, and fried dumplings. I personally also like the dumplings in chili oil and double cooked fish. Dry pot style rabbit was meh because rabbit has more bone than meat. Crispy rice style was also just alright because the crispy rice itself was not really tasty. Rice ball soup for dessert was the worst dish we've tried here.

Service here is slow unfortunately, so don't go here if you're in a rush.

Three Words: Dan Dan Noodles.
Get them. Savor them. Request another order of them. 

I was first introduced to Han Dynasty after attending the "Science of Spiciness" event through the Philadelphia Science Festival (nerdy, I know, but super informative and not to mention delicious!). I was thoroughly impressed by the quality of food samples that were provided and even more impressed at their ability to make your eyes water from their spice blend!

After this initial encounter, my person and I decided to try other options offered through the menu and Han Dynasty did NOT disappoint. There are a number of dishes I would recommend besides the Dan Dan Noodles, like: Spicy Crispy Cucumbers, Dumplings in Chili Oil, and the Kung Pao Style Chicken. What's great about this place is that you can either crank up the heat or simmer it down from the default spiciness of each dish, which is denoted by a red number by each item on the menu! But beware, this place is certainly not like other places and their spice blend forces you to drink a gallon of water to cool down your taste buds. Those that enjoy the heat, start with a 7 and work your way up! Those who don't, I would stick to a 3 or lower!

Han Dynasty is legit and Love their family style platters. Great for groups and could order a few things to share. I do wish they'd bring back their garlic wings. Despite the heartbreak from the wings there's a good selection from noodle dishes and ability to customize spice levels.

Han Dynasty, you disappointed me this weekend. I have been to the Old City location, the University City location, and the New York location. I would definitely give the NYC location 4 stars but my experience at the University City location two nights ago warranted a solid 3 stars, which is disappointing.

I remember  coming here a lot two/three years ago when the location first opened. It was so hyped and definitely lived up to it. Happy hour drinks were delicious and cheap. Food was high quality. Service was respectable. I'm really not sure what happened since then.

We had a group of 11 Friday night, which led to us sitting at one of the large round tables in the back. I've sat there before and have had no problems, but service was EXTREMELY bad when we went. The restaurant was also not packed or filled at the time, which is why I consider it to be totally inexcusable. We were always out of tea / water and our food took so long. We ordered two orders of Dan Dan noodles, one order of cold sesame noodles, dry fry style pork, kung pao chicken, scallion style beef, garlic style chicken, and black bean style beef. I had to ask the waiter multiple times to check on our food. Our original waiter was so incompetent and in the middle of waiting for our food another waitress started serving us.

The one piece of advice for food I have is to NOT order the garlic style unless you like bamboo. Shit was naasty. The dish came out incredibly orange looking and the taste of bamboo was sooo strong (and I hate hate hate bamboo... I failed to read the instruction and assumed it'd be... garlic? Not a stockpile of bamboo shoots?) and I personally just hated it.

The meal came out ridiculously cheap because we had such a large group and didn't order that much. It was around $11 a person since we ordered so little. We ended up just eating plain rice between dishes because they were coming out so slowly so that's probably why...

In New York, I often order 2 dan dan noodles and 3-4 dishes between only two people (almost way too much food for two), which totals up to around $40/person, which is on the expensive side for sure, so this was a nice change to only pay $11.

If you can get past the mediocre service though, the food is very authentic and most dishes are delicious!

Always a favorite of mine. How they manage to balance out spicy-ness with good flavor is beyond me. Everything about my dining experience was great -- flavor, portions, and overall restaurant atmosphere. Every single time I go, I always order something new on the menu and I'm never disappointed. But the classics on the menu to me are the kung pao chicken, dumplings in chili oil, and the spicy cucumbers.

Always amazing!! Great service and outstanding food. Each one of their locations has slightly different recipes (as it is customary for Chinese chefs to put slightly personal touches on dishes) but this one is the absolute BEST. 

I've been to all locations and it's incredible how much better this one is than the others. To be clear though, you're going to have an amazing meal at all of them. Just go to U City if you can. Much love!!

Delicious food, great atmosphere. We went for a 3pm lunch on a Friday and were seated immediately. They had lots of pandemic adjustments in place, tables are very clean and spaced out, and we felt safe eating indoors.
We shared Singapore noodles, which had plenty of chicken and shrimp. We ordered chicken and shiitake mushroom steamed dumplings, but I couldn't taste the mushrooms. It is possible we got chicken only, but I was too hungry to care and wolfed them down anyway.
Note that the restaurant's entrance is right on Chestnut St and not off the patio that runs down the side of the bldg.

It was great.  We especially loved the scallion pancake appetizer.  Our server was awesome. The only reason we give it 4 stars, is that we ordered the garlic sauce meal with tofu because my husband is trying to be vegetarian.  I am not a fan of tofu, so it probably wasn't their fault I wasn't a 100% fan

Beef. It's what's for dinner. 

But I ordered tofu! It wasn't until I consumed my dish did I realize that it wasn't what I ordered. Han Dynasty successfully tricked a long-time vegetarian into eating meat. I thought I was safe there; I had been before. 

The server was very apologetic and said they would rush a new dish out to me. When it came, it felt like the same amount of time had gone by since my first order. The dish was devoid of flavor and my spice level was in the negative; it came as a three, I asked for a five. I ate it anyway because I was so hungry. 

When the check came, my dish was incorrect and a few dollars more than what I asked for. The same server apologized again and brought me the correct check. 

After paying, I chatted with the manager about the situation. He offered a halfhearted apology saying that they are without a head chef and that was the cause of the day's unfortunate events. I was particularly upset that because of them I ate meat. I think that's pretty egregious; the manager saw it as a mild inconvenience.

Excellent option nearby the Wharton campus! Even for groups of 5-6, I've never had to wait during lunch time, and the staff here consistently provides speedy service. They offer complimentary hot tea, which is clutch on a cold winter day...

Countless menu options to choose from, and my favorite thing about their entrees is the spice level. Regardless of what dish you order, you can choose from a range (1- way too mild through 10- you will likely cry), depending on how you like your food cooked. I think the 7/8 is my sweet spot- pun intended.

Han Dynasty doesn't skimp on the portion sizes either. Lunch specials are usually ~$8-10/each, but you can upgrade to a dinner portion for an extra couple bucks. I've enjoyed the kung pao, dry pepper, and garlic chicken/beef dishes. Would definitely come back next time I'm in the area.

As a lover of spicy szechuan food, I was super excited to try Han Dynasty and was not disappointed! Looks like this place is pricey from glancing at the menu, but keep in mind that everything is family style portions. 

Ordered the Dan Dan noodles at everyone's recommendation along with the dry chicken hot pot. The noodles were a flavor explosion, but not exactly my favorite mainly because I felt the peanut was a little overwhelming. I would definitely order the chicken dry hot pot again and again! A great combination of spicy, sweet, and sour. The only complaint was that it was a touch oily.

Would like to come back and try some more dishes, overall a good choice for a "higher end" Chinese/szechuan food experience.
Ordered soup from them and it was delivered so hot it burnt the whole inside of my mouth.

My family and I recently visited Han Dynasty University City location and had a wonderful night out! Service was great as usual.   Food, excellent.   We had salt and pepper wings,  house lo mein, spicy cucumbers,  scallion pancakes,  kung pao shrimp and double cooked fish.   My children love double cooked fish so much we have to place two orders.   Family style dining is great,  allowing on to try many different foods.  The flexibility in spice level is also pretty cool.
Make reservations, it can get crowded during lunch time. Food is a hit or miss for me. Today ordered exactly the same selections as 2 weeks ago and the bill was $5 more. How is that possible?!

I really love Han Dynasty. This location is a bit more casual than the other location down in Old City (I like to go there when I want to feel fancy). The food is still just as amazing as the other location, and the same great service is upheld. The tables are a bit packed in, but I guess that means business gets booming on weekends. I've never been here on a weekend, but I can imagine it's a prime location for college dates since its right in University City. The Wonton Soup is so good, I could eat a giant bowl of it every day. The Dan Dan Noodles are also one of my go to mood lifting foods. I've never been disappointed here.
A must go to when we're near Penn. Love the Dan Dan noodles (no pork) and Eggplant. Hope you like spice - definitely can turn up the heat. Definitely a fan!

The food was excellent. I have rarely been challenged by Philadelphia 's so-called spicy dishes, but their 'dry pot' wok packed a punch much to my pleasure. Their bartender, however, was very miserly in her pour. If you hate 3 oz pours in $11 specialty cocktails as much as I do, order a damn beer!

Love this place! Food was amazing. Atmosphere was amazing. Service was amazing. String beans are to die for, along with the salt and pepper shrimp and the Dan Dan noodles. I love how you can adjust the spice level to things that you order. A new fave for me!
Go to place. Always loved their food. Have tried  almost everything available for a vegetarian, and there are all of options . Loved almost everything.

We went here for my graduation party this weekend with a group of 13. We did the tasting menu at the $25 level and it was amazing. I can't imagine what they offer in the $30 level menu because our dinner included lobster, whole-fish, and duck (and could have included rabbit, but we declined) in addition to all the more everyday kinds of ingredients (chicken, veg, beef, pork, tofu, homemade noodles, etc). Everything was beautifully presented, delicious, and abundant, and the service was wonderful. Our waiter, Anthony, was a gem. He was really friendly, knew everything there was to know about the food, and seemed to always be right there when we had a request or question. We had a couple of folks in the crowd with dietary issues- couldn't handle spice, didn't eat pork, etc. and Anthony made sure that there were plenty of options to accommodate their needs. Can't say enough good about this place. By far, the best Chinese food in Philly that I've tried, and it has a classy atmosphere, extremely professional waitstaff, and possibly the least expensive prix fixe in town (there is a $20/pp option too!).

This place had some pretty solid Chinese food. I came here with four others, and we ordered a bunch of dishes which were all pretty big, but we managed to finish everything! 

Chili wontons - 3/5 - the sauce was a little more sour than I expect.
Chili cucumbers - 4/5 - not traditional but I liked the sweet and sour sauce.
West lake beef soup - 1/5 - not good at all, the soup was so bland and the beef in the soup was very dry. 
Dry pepper chicken - 5/5 - so yummy! The seasoning was good and the chicken did not have too much breading and no bones!
Hot sauce fish - 5/5 - flavor was really good, spicy!
Scallion style lamb - 3.5/5 - I'm not a huge fan of this dish in general and it was alright. 
Dry pot intestines - 4.5/5 - a little oily but very delicious! The flavor was great and there was a lot of intestines :) 

Aside from the soup, I thought everything was pretty good, but coming from California, we also have a lot of great Chinese food so it didn't wow me. Solid and good spicy food though. Rice is also included for free which is nice!

My friends told me that the Dan Dan noodles are amazing, but I didn't get a chance to try those. Maybe next time!

Had to come here while visiting CHOP. I can see why this place has gained some great reviews. I want to give 5 but alas 4 from me. They say they can adjust the spicy level but they didn't to any of the dishes. It's okay though, just sweated it out.

The dan dan noodles was the star. Holy smokes. My baby girl loved it too. Everything we had was really good, except for the heat level. Lol. Besides the noodles, the beef dry pot style (got lunch portion which doesn't come with the stirrup heat), mapo tofu (prob one of the best sauce I've tasted), and the spicy cucumbers (it's a rather large dish). 

One good thing too, free soda refills. Come early or make reservations. Came here for lunch when it opened. Food does come out very fast too.

The flavor of the food is so good no matter what you order!  I have seen reviews about the service but I always have the same lady who is probably an owner. There is a language barrier, but it is also cultural. She is so quiet but will talk. Best place I have eaten for this type of restaurant.

Overall Value: Strong flavors, quality, and decent portion sizes (eh, probably could be bigger) make up for the slight upcharge over the hole-in-the-wall places that we typically prefer.  

The Food:  We ended up getting a feast.  We ordered the scallion pancake ($3.95) and beef tendons in chili oil ($9.95) for appetizers.  The scallion pancake was fairly standard and unremarkable.  The beef tendons in chili oil - my wife was quite proud of how far I've come in terms of openness to different food (I'm at "level 2 ordering") - were really good. 
 They are super thin with a little chew, and really soak up the chili oil to make for a fairly spicy dish (it was the spiciest dish we had, although it is not going to come close to the actual spice levels we had in China).  

For entrees, we ordered the dry pot style with pork entree ($15.95) and the crispy rice style with chicken entree ($14.95), as well as the bok choy with black mushrooms ($12.95).  The dry pot style was the star of the show - really bold flavors, and the pork was very tender.  We kept the spice level at 10, which really ended up being only a medium spice level.  But still excellent flavor, and the mini wok it is served in is great presentation (and keeps the dish warm).  The crispy rice style is always fun to eat because the rice has a nice chew to it, and can really soak up the sauce.  It was slightly too sweet for my liking, but the chicken was also very tender and the dish complemented the dry pot style pretty well.  The bok choy with black mushrooms is also a bit of a sweeter dish, but it was cooked well and the mushrooms were plump with great flavor.  We also ended up getting a free cumin style with tofu entree by accident, which ended up being a freebie (who am I to say no?).  The tofu was a bit too dry, but great strong cumin flavor on the dish (and I'm not complaining because we were not charged).
