Service: We had to wait 5 minutes for a table, which made no sense because there were a ton of tables open.  But once we got seated, our server was great.  He also was really nice to box up the leftovers for us (and even threw in some extra rice).  Overall very good service.

Space and pace: Huge interior with really tasteful decor.  It was mostly filled with students (no shock, given the location) but I think it is also a fine place to bring a date or family.  Definitely on the list of places for when my mother-in-law visits.

I don't mean to oversell it, but this is the best f'in restaurant with the friendliest staff on the planet. I've brought people like Steve Wozniak and Felicia Day to this location as part of a conference for a pre-event speakers' dinner, and they've always knocked it out of the park. Double Lobster, are you kidding me?! The drinks are mixed strong (try the cocktail specials!), so be sure to have your party boots on.

Try the szechuan style french fries even though they're not on the menu - simply amazing!

Most dishes also have vegetarian alternatives.

Like almost every Yelp review mentions, the $8 Dan Dan Noodles here are amazingly good and an automatic 5/5.

Note: I've heard that if you get the dan dan noodles to go, ask for the sauce on the side so that the noodles don't get too soggy by the time you get home to eat them.

Han Dynasty has a simple and modern interior decor, which is a nice step above your typical Chinese restaurants. They also have spacious indoor and outdoor seating. The service was good, and they have a plethora of menu items accompanied by a 1-10 spice scale for spicy dishes to help you decide what to eat. The dan dan noodles were 6 on the spice scale, and I could handle them with just a bit of water, thanks to my gochujang (Korean spicy red paste) training. The noodles, which come with minced pork, were incredibly flavorful and satisfying to eat. You know that spicy food is good when the heat makes you want even more despite any pain you might feel, and Han Dynasty's dan dan noodles meet that requirement. The portion was also a large amount! I finished about 4/5 of the serving on my own for dinner; it's very worth the price!

I tried the $7 Chicken Fried Dumplings appetizer, which consists of 6 small dumplings and soy sauce. The dumplings were good, but skippable and not that worth it. I recommend coming in a group of 3 or more people, sharing two dan dan noodle orders per every 3 people, and trying some of their meat and/or vegetable family-style dishes!

Han Dynasty blew me away; by far, they offer the best dan dan noodles I've ever had. I recommend Han Dynasty to anyone visiting Philly!

I've come to Han Dynasty several times but realized I had never written a review! On my last visit, I came here in a group of 7 for lunch on a Saturday. We had a short amount of time to eat before we had to get to class, and the waiters were very understanding and accommodating.

It was a chilly day and I was thankful for unlimited hot tea. I've enjoyed all of the dishes I've ordered in the past, and on this particular visit, I ordered the Eggplant with Garlic Sauce. It was amazing - perfectly spiced and tender. The portion was huge, so I was able to take leftovers for later. 

I definitely recommend Han Dynasty for tasty food, good-sized portions, and attentive service!

When I was told I'd be picking the dinner location for a recruiting trip back on campus, I immediately knew Han Dynasty would be it. Although I had only been here about twice during my time at Penn, I still remembered how good all of the dishes were and especially the dan dan noodles (definitely get these!). The experience did not disappoint, and the restaurant seemed quite full on a Tuesday evening. I had the dan dan noodles as well as the lamb cumin style, both of which were terrific. I would say that the spiciness levels may have been dampened down a bit for western tastes as I didn't think I was tasting a 6 or 7 out of 10 (both of which my dishes were purported to be). If I get the opportunity to come back to Penn again, you know I will be here!

This 4 star review is an average of my experience over the past 6 years (5 star or 10 star if yelp allows me) and recent experiences (3 star). In my opinion, it used to be the best szechuan places in West Philly. However in the past 1 year, their spice level has reduced a lot. I tried by specifically requesting to have a very high spice level for dishes which are already rated 10, but it still ended up to be very bland. While I understand that it might be in an effort to match with the spice level of other people, I will expect to have the previous spice level on requests. Currently I am going to the Han at Old City whenever I am having a craving of Szechuan as their dishes still provide the kick that I love, but since I work at UPenn, the one at University City is more accessible. Han at University City, are you listening?
Never a dull moment; never a disappointment; never a lack of seasoning. The ambiance is great, and the food is outstanding!

Good spicy food. I enjoy the dan dan noodles (spicier than the rating would indicate) and have ordered them every time I've gone. The dry pot (my favorite is the fish...had it with rabbit before, which was full of bone shards) that's rated a 10 isn't actually that spicy--it has a "ma la" quality to it, which means it leaves a tingly sensation, as opposed to heat on your tongue and throat. The spicy beef noodles are also pleasantly tingly and the broth is flavorful. The mapo tofu is only ok.

No complaints about this place! Been meaning to get here for years now (west philly and old city), and I finally got there Xmas eve. While they weren't doing their lunch specials, we enjoyed the regular menu. I got the crispy rice with fish, which comes in an extremely large dish, but it's a lot of sauce so it's not as overwhelmingly large as it seems. The kung pao chicken is a favorite, and the food came literally within 5 minutes of ordering it, which was weird, but I was hungry so I appreciated it!!! I'll definitely come back (when someone else is paying).
Great food and atmosphere.  Some dishes are better than others however - still it seems pretty authentic.  On second visit everything was outstanding.

Thanks to the suggestion of local Yelpers, I was made aware to try Han Dynasty. Lunch at Han was my just reward for taking a 7am flight from Chicago before my work meetings. Tip for Lunch: Noon-1pm is super crowded. Come earlier or later.

Everything at Han has a number on its spicy scale. My server was great, and she immediately asked what I could handle, and described the spiciness as a "Sriracha-type spicy". I would love if you could get a Han t-shirt with a spicy number on it! I'm a 6! I'm an 8!

- Dan Dan Noodles- 8 Spicy (my server pronounced it "Don don")
Excellent! Does contain small amounts of pork, not sure if you can get it vegetarian friendly. This noodle bowl was enough for a meal, for sure, and very spicy.

Still, I had to try an entrée too, on my short visit to Philadelphia. 

- Double Cooked Style chicken (4 Spicy), with leeks, hot peppers, fermented black beans, and chili oil. My server suggested Double Cooked as her favorite, so I went with it. It was good, but not super amazing. Cumin Style may have been more up my alley. 

They have a great drink and beer selection, and I ordered the Oskar Blues Dale's Pale Ale simply to cut through some of the spiciness. (Ha, right!) Happy Hour is 5-7pm here. (Has anyone else noticed the website address could also be interpreted as "Handy Nasty.net"? Like, too bad that "Fixit guy" is out of a good URL!) I'm very much looking forward to a return to Han Dynasty.

Tried this place out for the first time and was easily impressed. Dry pepper style wings were amazing. Scallion Style beef was okay, and house rice noodles were just average. Got 2 drinks, ice tea and punch, were both fantastic. Will visit again.
Ate here for lunch with friends on a visit to Philly and it was quite good--very different from my experience 4 years ago. Service was good, food was good, no complaints!

An epic fail on so many counts. A true tragicomedy. Possibly because a friend had talked it up and we didn't realize it only was for the spicy dry entrees...

Three of us ordered Spicy Beef Noodles. Now, generally speaking, beef noodles and beef noodle soup does not come in a bowl of chili oil. It's in a soy sauce-based soup with some chili paste or chilis. Our noodles were drenched in oil, and it was disgusting. Sure, I read the Chinese and it said "Szechuan beef noodles" but nowhere on the menu did it say "will arrive in a BOWL of chili oil." Two of my friends asked to switch to the other soup, but still, the noodles were slick in oil and slimy. 

Then there was the "Crispy Rice style." Excuse me, what crispy rice? The dish arrived with vegetables soaked in cornstarch and sauce on top, so obviously the rice at the bottom was no longer crispy when it arrived on the table. The vegetables and pork were covered in a super vinegary sauce - it was so sour that there was no "sweet," as mentioned on the menu.

And the final horror - the order of dumplings. I have never even seen dumplings that looked as terrible as they tasted. These? Gods forbid I ever have to even see it. One bite and my friend was done with the dumplings. 

The only decent dish was a friend's spicy dry pepper style, because it's hard to mess up fried chicken when half the dish is chili peppers.

None of these dishes had any complexity of flavor you'd find in a proper Szechuan (or any style of regional Chinese) restaurant. These dishes were even worse than most American-Chinese takeout foods. Even Panda Express tastes better than the horror show we were presented with.

Excited to eat some Chinese delivery but was disappointed as we specified less spice for 2 simple dishes and could barely eat it. Lo Mein with chicken and one with veg, never in my life had these dishes with so much spice. Not sure if it was a mistake or that's how spicy the less spice really is?! Tried to wash off the spice but it was still spicy

Loved their preparation! My family of four was well-fed with leftovers from the 3 dishes we carried out. I really enjoyed the Hot Sauce Tofu with white rice! The Dry Pepper chicken was perfectly crispy and super savory. The Cumin Style Chicken was SO spicy!! My whole family was winded from eating this. I loved the flavor, but if we get it again we will definitely have to get it less spicy (they didn't ask for a spice preference on that, so next time I would probably say medium spice because it was definitely high spice).

I must start off by saying that a few friends and I were drawn to come here purely because of the hype. We had heard countless students in University City hype this place up and tell us how great the Dan Dan Noodles and other menu items were.

We had made a reservation ahead of time, and we came in at the time of it and were seated promptly. Once we had placed our orders of 'Chicken Dumplings' and 'Dan Dan Noodles,' we waited to receive our food. Upon trying the 'Dan Dan Noodles ,' me and my 2 other friends were grossed out by the flavor. With a description of having peanut sauce, this seemed like something we were interested in. However, the noodles tasted more like straight peanut oil, and they left a very sticky residue on the tongue. 

Although it was kind of awkward, we were able to have our waited take them back, and take our new orders for us. Upon waiting for our new orders of 'Garlic Sauce Style' chicken, we were served our dumplings, which were mediocre at best. They tasted kind of like packaged ones that I buy at the grocery store.

A manager of some sort came up to us to ask about what we didn't like about the 'Dan Dan Noodles,' which I appreciated but also felt bad about.

Once our main dishes of 'Garlic Sauce Style' chicken came out, they were SO salty. I just felt like I was eating thin strips of chicken with so much salt and garlic. 

Although I came in with high expectations, I'm so sad to say that none of the food even lived up to average quality. I do feel bad saying this, because I know many fans of the restaurant. The customer service was also decent. 

Sorry, but due to the prices and quality of the food, I definitely wouldn't come again. From a huge fan of all types of Asian food, I was left nothing but disappointment.

Best Chinese food on campus! I've taken my international Chinese friends  here and they love this place and it gets as close to authentic as you can get on campus. I usually order the dry pot style beef which is delicious. The lo mein here is also very good. I also really enjoy the eggplants with garlic sauce here. The spice level for all all dishes is customizable and I've never had any issues. The restaurant is a little on the pricier side for Chinese food; however, it is worth it unless you have the time to trek to Chinatown.
Superb lunch of Dandan noodles, shrimp with honey and walnuts, eggplant and garlic, and mapo tofu. All dishes were wonderful. Great service. Can't wait to go back.

This place is legend in more than one friends circle I roll with. 
It was pretty good. I don't know how anyone orders over level 5 here. Everything's hot and Spicy and full of peppers. Everything. 
It was very good but kinda hurt my tummy later. Maybe I need to order a level 3. 
We all shared stuff. The thing I got for myself was dry pepper chicken. 
We got 6 meals for $74 at lunch. They get expensive for dinner.
Dan Dan noodle was exceptional. Chicken with garlic sauce was delicious! I tried 2 new beers that were awesome. Our server was attentive and informative. Definitely will return 6

DO NOT COME here! They have RATS running around in the restaurant.
I came here to Jan 10th 2022 at 7pm. It was shocking to see the rat just running in the seating area. I run without looking back.
Some customers sitting there said they saw it for 20 minutes, and the manager just let it happen. When I left, the manager ( blond hair lady) even tried to explain that the rat was from outside running into their restaurant. It is not a good excuse at all. 
I am seriously concerned about the health and safety of this place. It is a high end restaurant with high cost Food, not the cornerstone so this is unacceptable!

the dan dan noodles, potstickers, fried rice, and spring rolls are fantastic. the scallion pancakes are also delicious. 

service is friendly. everyone has a good handle on the menu, and are open to provide recommendations. good for dine in and takeout. 

only gripe is that sometimes the spice level can be out of control - even if you ask for mild. If you can take extreme heat in your food, then this isn't a problem for you.

One of my favorite spots to eat in University City. And a great place to go if you're hungry as the food comes out so fast!

Cumin Lamb - You can't go wrong with this, lamb stir fried with onions and bell peppers
Garlic Sauce Chicken - My favorite, stir fried with carrots and a slightly sweet sauce
Braised Beef Noodles - Great flavor, chewy noodles and tender beef

This was enough for 3 people to leave with their bellies full. I also love their dry pepper fish and dan dan noodles. This is one of my go-to spots for authentic Chinese food and I love how quickly all the dishes come out.

This place was great!! Goodness...what didn't we have! We started with the spicy cucumbers, spring rolls, scallion pancakes, and Dan Dan noodles! Can I be honest....from posted pictures the Dan Dan noodles didn't look all that great but our server recommended them and they were delicious.... get the sauce on the bottom!!! :) Then we had the dry pot beef which was okay, kind of oily. The Kung pao chicken was my favorite!!! Great flavor! Best dish! We also had the honey walnut shrimp which was a honey battered shrimp and is recommended. The walnuts were just sitting on the plate and we kind of expected them to be included with the batter - still good though. The garlic chicken was okay and the fried rice was terrible. Don't get the fried rice! 

Overall, it was a great dinner and experience. Our server Lu Lu was super good! Very knowledgeable attentive, and helpful! Ask for her! She helped make our experience great! Thank you. I will go back when I'm in Philly again!

I have not had a meal at Han for so long and decided to go on a Sunday 1 pm, thinking it is still warm if we sat under the sun. 

I have to say the food is not as good as before COVID, the taste and the ingredients users were just average   And the hardest part of market street is busy and dusty it probably is not a good choice to dine outside
The food and the service are both above average to very good - it's a fun experience overall.

Solid food, nice place overall. Loved the crunchy spicy cucumber appetizer - the sauce is delicious. The chicken in garlic sauce was tasty as well. Dumplings were fine, skip the hot pickled vegetables though.

My second time at Han Dynasty was as pleasurable as the first. I went with my coworker friends, Robert and Ingrid, a couple who share my love for authentic Asian food. We each ordered and shared our family style dishes of Dan Dan Noodles, Spicy Beef Noodle Soup, and Taiwanese Sausage Fried Rice. Whoa... these dishes were simply amazing! Plentiful portions packed with so much heat, they were fine examples of how spicy hot food can be quite enjoyable. I've had the Dan Dan Noodles here before and recommended it to Robert. He and Ingrid loved the dish. Ground bits of pork, peanut sauce, and chili oil. So simple and yet so addictive. My Spicy Beef Noodle Soup tingled my lips with its exotic flavor that was equally as addictive as the Dan Dan Noodles. The beef and tendon chunks were very tender. I just wish there was more meat. The Taiwanese Sausage Fried Rice was the most ordinary of the three, but it was like the superior quality fried rice you get at Chinese weddings. "This is one the best meals I've had in my entire life," Robert admitted. "Even better than our wedding?" Ingrid challenged. "It's right up there with that," he replied. That's the best endorsement you can get!

When Han Dynasty's University City location opened up, it was a godsend for all college students in the area. It is hands down my favorite restaurant in the neighborhood, and probably my most frequented as well.

At this point, I've lost track of all the different menu items I have ordered over the past couple of years. Sharing is the name of the game, so be sure to order to your heart (or stomach's) content. 

For appetizers, the tripe in chili oil is divine. The Dan Dan noodles are a must-get as well, by consensus. 

As for entrees, I like how Han Dynasty lets you choose your preparation style first and then your choice of protein. It certainly allows for a great deal of variety. Just some of my suggestions include the cumin pork, dry pot fish, and double cooked pork belly. Also, a gem located among the specials is the three cup chicken: both sweet and savory and prepared in a hot bowl so it stays warm.

My only regret with Han Dynasty is that I have never made it to its happy hour. The full bar is underrated, and one of the best cocktail places on this side of the Schuylkill. With great food and drink, Han Dynasty really has it all. No wonder there's always a wait in the evenings.

This is my favorite restaurant in Philadelphia. Since the first trip, I have been back about 20 times in the past 11 months. It redeemed itself from its first subpar performance. 

My go to dishes:

1) Spicy beef noodle soup. Its go for dining in and good to go. It's delightfully spicy and has a mix of chewy cuts of beef with tendon. 

2) Bok choy with black mushrooms. Always well done, the vegetables are flavorful, with the black mushrooms soaking up a bit f extra sauce. 

3) All of the spicy meat dishes are excellent. If you're up for something on the spicy end of the spectrum, the dry pot style, is the way to go. It is good with any pairing of meats. On the more mild end is the double cook style, which is very flavorful, and the Kung pao style, which is better than any other Kung pao dish I have ever had. 

The only other time I was disappointed in the food at Han Dynasty, is when I ordered off of the special menu. In my opinion, if you can't appreciate just little bit of spice, you may be better off dining elsewhere. I have had the shrimp and walnut, the roasted duck, and a lobster dish. All were subpar in my book. Try the previously mentioned dishes instead. 

Best Chinese food, and in my mind, best food overall in Philadelphia.

This was the best Chinese food I've had in a decade. We got the garlic sauce shrimp and dry pot chicken and string beans (without pork) and the garlic sauce shrimp and string beans were the clear winners, though the other was exceptional as well. We tried to go back the next day, but they weren't open yet. We will certainly return soon!

No wonder the Han Dynasty is considered  a golden age in Chinese history because this place was a gold mine of good food. We ordered family style and would definitely recommend doing it that way as you are able to try a lot of different things. Was only able to get a picture of the bok choi because we devoted everything else. Overall great experience, would recommend.

They extended the place!  When you walk in, the extension is to your left.  Although I did not make a stroll through it, it looks very lounge like and very nice.  They also have a cell phone charger!

Anyway, sorry Han for the star retraction.  Good news, the spicy cucumbers still has not failed to disappoint :)  And therefore, I still love dipping the scallion pancakes into it.  However, it just seems like those are the two things I can consistently enjoy (plus the dan dan noodles).  MF and I got the Scallion Style Lamb (stir fried in hoisin and oyster sauce with onions, scallions, and your choice of meat).  Though the sauce itself was good, the meat did not taste like lamb.  When we asked the server just to make sure, she was kind of cold about it.  Lamb has a distinct flavor, and this tasted pretty much like beef.  Sometimes I would get a hint of lamb.  So, if you want the Scallion Style, do not get the lamb.  You are paying extra money for something that tastes essentially like beef.  I'm not saying they're lying or being dishonest, but it's just weird.    

The drinks were ok.  We got some sort of punch that had coconut creme in it and it was quite blah for $9.  So I woudn't get that either.

The service from our officially designated waitress was just a bucket of suck.  She was not attentive.  She never came back to check up on anything.  She did not refill tea/water.  Also, wecame with two other people.  So two entrees = two bowls of rice.  OK, so you gave one small  bowl, but never thought about refilling it and that pricked my nerves.

NOT a fan of the University City Service.  The past two times have been below average.

I love this place.  Okay, maybe it's more of an obsession.  I know what's gonna happen when we go.  Dan dan noodles, so perfectly rich and spicy that I end up eating the whole bowl.  Spicy cucumbers - used to be better but my wife insists on ordering them every time - so I end up eating the whole bowl.  And then I eat the whole plate of double cooked fish.  You get the idea.  Yes, there is usually a stomachache at the end of the experience, but you have to go "10" for spice.  Go big or go home, right?

This is an overdue review of the 2nd Philly location of my beloved spice palace (https://www.yelp.com/biz/han-dynasty-philadelphia)!

But its also taken awhile because, despite popping in for a couple years now I've only really done take out when situations like Clark Park Fest meetings have brought me out to West Philly and I found myself craving some food on the go. This is also why I'm giving 4 stars for now, but the fact that they do things like free parking redemption for a lot of 37th & Filbert may have me changing this!

But while it's definitely not as big as my beloved Old City spot, and you might not see Han as much, this location is a good sized one that plays true to his style. It was also the first Han Dynasty to have a bar, and features some pretty impressive cocktails like the Shifu's tea which marries Old Overholt rye whiskey with Wang Lao Ji sweet tea, Chinese bitters, lemonade, and hibiscus bitters; and Han's Cup which combines Bulleit Rye with Pimm's No. 1 Sichuan Bitters. Toss in a rotating beer list and you have a solid bar.

In my three Old City reviews I touched on plenty of the things that make Han Dynasty awesome overall. So for this one I may as well touch on some of my favorite entrees:

Dan Dan Noodles - No explanation needed really because you already know. whether you go pork or veggie, or alter the spice to your preference they're the king!

Rabbit w/ peanuts in chili oil - the tender meat and super spice makes going through all those tiny bones worth it!

Fried Taiwanese sausage - sweet succulent meat pockets!

Cumin style lamb - My usual go to entree with its perfect levels of spice, bell peppers blended with long hots, and amazing cumin crust. 

Double cooked pork belly - My kind of pork belly!

Dry pepper style beef - Triple flash fried in all of those pepper juices!

Ok this is based on one Grubhub delivery that was accurate, on time, well packed, and undamaged. So no problems there. And I have been to Han Dynasty's before and this one in particular, several times. I don't think I have ever had a meal I would rate less than "fair" and most of the food I have had there I would rate "good".

So why the low rating? Simply because the meal I received tonight was awful. I don't feel entirely well after eating it, I'm suspicious of MSG poisoning. I said nothing about holding MSG so this is on me. But putting my feeling unwell aside, the food was just hopelessly mediocre. Soggy oily string beans, dried out odd tasting and nagging home style tofu, and seriously mediocre and salty chicken with scallions. Just wow. Not what I expected.

I love everything about this place. I've been going to HD for years and have never had a bad experience. I usually get the same thing every time but almost anything you get is going to be great. 

I always start with dan-dan noodles and dumplings in chil oil. Then for the main course I get the dry pepper chicken or fish, kung-pao chicken or tofu, and garlic beef. 

The U-City location tends to be a little Spicer than the others so be prepared for that. This place is awesome check it out!

I love Han!

Pros:
Accommodate for vegetarian needs very nicely! (Veg Dan Dan noodles are lovely!)
Portion size is really good - and makes it affordable on student  budgets. (Think one dish, two people, plus leftovers )
Friendly staff
Love the decor in old city branch 
Love the spice level variability 

Fave items on menu:
Scallion pancakes
Kung pao style 
Cumin style 
Dan Dan noodle
Visited again 12/10/21 - Food is fine, no lunch menu, tables are a close to each other as before pandemics. Sitting two feet away from a large party was very uncomfortable.

THREE CUP CHICKEN! Let me say it one more time for the people in the back... THE THREE CUP CHICKEN!!!! This dish was a highlight from my recent takeout order and I can't wait to order it again. The perfect amount of sweet and savory flavors, tenderness, and garlic.

I was in the mood for soup so I ordered a beef noodle soup from Han Dynasty for pickup. While looking through the other menu options online, I noticed the Three Cup Chicken in the specials section. I decided to try it. Based on the way the menu describes the items, I could not tell if this was going to come with rice or not. I assumed (and hoped) it would, and it did. You just never know with takeout these days!

I scheduled it for a later pickup time, ran my errands, and stopped by a few minutes earlier than expected for my food. While it wasn't ready when I got there (100% my fault) they did get it wrapped up quickly and I did not have to wait long. By the time I got home everything was still hot and VERY delicious.

There's good and then there's places you dream about nightly and obsess over.  Han Dynasty is the latter.  

I've eaten the entire menu, many times over, never in one sitting but this is one of the rare restaurants that I go that I force myself to order something different every time.  It is all good.  Of course there's always the favorites that I have to get (most of them packed into delis for a late night snack, breakfast and lunch the next day).  

Dan Dan Noodles and Scallion Pancakes are a must have.  And if you're going to eat them there, order seconds to take home.  There is nothing better than a bowl of Dan Dan with a side of Scallion pancakes; you'll thank me later.  

My ultimate though is the hot pot, super spicy, with chili oil on the side.  The heat from the chili oil hurts so bad it's good...too bad When Harry met Sally it wasn't in Han Dynasty.  Then the sichuan peppercorns kick in with their insane numbing effects on your tongue and lips.  Your body doesn't know what to do, worry about the heat or the fact that your lips are vibrating like a quarter operated bed in a cheap motel.  Yes, the hot pot is my ultimate pleasure.

Ordered from here a second time during our visit to Philly - no complaints this time! We asked for medium spice level so the food was perfectly spicy. Flavors were impeccable. I loved the Garlic Sauc Style Chicken and Dan Dan Noodles a lot! Would recommend both of these.

I came here after Anthony Bourdain gave his stamp of approval, in the recent 'The Layover' episode.  I have to preface my review, that after this visit for Chinese, which seems to be the best of the best, I just don't like the cuisine. It's not something I'm drawn too if I had the choice.
That being said, husband and I came in here with my parents in tow for lunch last week.  The staff was uber friendly and our sweet waitress helped navigate us through the menu. The red numbers indicate the level of 'hotness' she proclaimed, but any dish can be customized to your liking.  She also put the disclaimer that if things get to hot, sip on tea and eat more rice, don't drink water! She suggested the Dan Dan noodles, after numerous recommendation from fellow yelpers, we took the plunge.  I have to say they were nice, which just the right about of heat, left a warm tingle on the tongue and not swimming in old as the rest of the dishes we had. We had the dumplings in chili oil which as the name suggested was very oily.  We also ordered the veggie dumplings since the spicy was a tad bit too much for my parents, they liked the light dough pillow puff stuffed with cabbage and not doused in sauce.
For entrees, which arrived at our table as soon as they were cooked, I had the dry pot style, spicy level taken down to a 6, I was a bit disappointed since I assumed that it would as hot as the Dan Dan, but it seems there is a slight variance in the rating system. The dish was pretty at first glance but my protein selection (beef) was scarce, and I had to pick through the rest to find it.
Husband had the Dry Pepper Style taken down to a 7 and subsquently asked for more chili oil since he claimed that it wasn't hot enough. His dish again was lacking on the beef with an overabundance of peppers. My parents had the scallion style of beef which had no heat, and the ratio for chicken to veggie looked better balanced, again, swimming in sauce.
I should have went with the chalkboard special and gone all out for the Szechuan lobster, she said it was two WHOLE lobsters prepared  Szechuan style with something. something (she lost me after two whole lobsters) but I thought that would be too much for lunch, although upon leaving, an order was being presented to the table behind us and I did all I could to not drool over the platter, it was beautiful!!

The staff was very friendly, however we had a hard time trying to get someone several times to clear our finished dishes, we actually sat them on the counter across from us. None of us were bowled over by anything that we ate but it wasn't a bad lunch, but I'm going to go against the general consensus and give her a luke warm reception.

My boyfriend and I mostly cook at home, but we've found ourselves at Han Dynasty in West Philly on average once weekly. The staff there is incredible and go out of their way to accomodate, from the manager to the hostess to the wait staff. 

I eat gluten free, and every waiter I've had has been knowledgable about gluten free options or accomodations on the menu. My boyfriend is always looking for good suggestions and pairings, and the waiters have also been great about recommending dishes and drinks together. The food has always come out quickly and been exceptionally delicious.

We've brought several friends there, ad they've had similar positive experiences. I would definitely recommend Han Dynasty for quality Szechuan food!

Really disappointed with my latest order from here. I've ordered the same things multiple times before at the Manayunk location and have thought the food was excellent. When I ordered from this location, the food was much worse. The fish dry fry style was so spicy it was inedible. When we ordered it before in other locations it was well balanced and delicious. This was just a spicy mess (and we're good with spicy).

Hands down my favorite sichuan place in the east coast. Their dry pot and pepper style chicken are the best and will never get bored of it. I wish they had more locations especially a few in the west coast.
The greatest. Best ratio of authentic Szechuan cuisine to cost. For spicy, get Dan Dan noodle, spicy cucumber, and dry pot, for non spicy, get the scallion style and eggplant in sauce

Have been to their locations in Cherry Hill and NYC also.  They are my favorite spot for garlic sauce.  Hands down one of the best Chinese food restaurants and especially chicken with garlic sauce in the world.  Great place and service is always the best!

Hell no!! The worst dining in experience I have ever had in Philadelphia. Their waitresses express their strong discrimination to Asian customers, so impatient, disrespectful and didnt even take our orders! Guys, respect yourself and dont go to this restaurant!!!!! 

Have you ever seen a waitress rowed up their freaking eye bowl up? Have you experienced a waitress trying to copy your credit card that would potentially do fraud bank transfer for their own benefit? If you come here, these horrible thing would come true. If you Don't  Wanna lost your money and being despited, don't come here!!!!

Amazing. Probably the fanciest restaurant in the area. We come here for celebrations like birthday parties. 
Sometimes there's a wait but never long. The service is spectacular. And the food even better. I recommend the Dan Dan noodles. But everything here is pretty good. The best part is you can pick your spicy level. I enjoy a solid 8 out of ten. 
I believe we came here once for a party and did a special menu and it was like $30+ per person to get a whole buffet of foods to try. That was awesome.
There's something for everyone and it's just good food.

*Channeling William Shatner*

HAAAAAAAAAN!

I've tried Manayunk. That was insane. I told myself I could only come back once in a blue moon, lest I gorge myself into oblivion.

And then, biking to Center City from my house, I discover that you've soft opened a new location FOUR BLOCKS FROM WHERE I LIVE.

How could you do this to me?

I must honor it as a great gift. I must fear it as an infernal curse.

A tasty, peppery, punch someone in the face because it was so good kind of curse.

Your food makes me want to give up my imaginary first born (because, let's face it, who would ever have a kid with someone like me?) so I can imply, but not actually say, some sort of poorly conceived joke about your dry fry style dishes involving said baby.

Yes. That's what your food does to me.

Super friendly, quick service. A respectable beer/wine/cocktail list, and a beautiful space that used to be home to a restaurant that I've sadly never been to (MidAtlantic). This is all I need any day of the week.

So, it's obvious that this place is a regular staple for me now.

Bring 3 friends for lunch. Get the dan dan noodles, or cold sesame. Also, spicy cucumbers. Then add a dry fry dish, or their scallion style lamb, or whatever the hell you want, and everyone gets to eat tons of delicious Szechuan, face-melting awesomeness for about 10 bucks a head.

I still need to do some sort of food challenge here, where I eat the spiciest three things they can create. Who's in?

No baby sacrifice required.

I had an outstanding experience at Han Dynasty. Great mood. I am really happy that I wound up ordering Taiwanese Sausage, it was incredible, just a wonderful taste. The workers are very helpful. I would highly recommend Han Dynasty if you're looking for something different and cool.
Great spot for Chinese food. The food was fresh and very tasty. I ordered fried rice with a side of vegetables. Will definitely return.

I've been to Han Dynasty a bunch of times and while some of their food is a hit or miss, you'll still be happy with it. Their food is family style so they give large servings that are meant to be shared. 

I always order the fish dry pot with level 10 spicyness and it is delicious!! They bring the dish out in a pot with a candle underneath so your food will remain warm. The only downside to this is that the serving size is pretty small. 

The fish is cooked perfectly and it's so soft it basically melts in your mouth. They used to include a larger variation of vegetables with the fish but now it's mostly bamboo and mushroom that's edible. If you want to get the whole experience, I highly recommend getting the level 10 spicyness because you may tear up but the flavors are worth it. 

I have also tried the garlic sauce style tofu and chicken. It is just as good as it looks and they give a huge plate. It's basically bamboo, tofu/chicken, and mushrooms cooked in a thick reddish sauce. 

The chicken fried rice is better than most places and once again, it's a huge serving. It does have plenty of veggies and chicken. 

I would not recommend getting the cold sesame noodles though. They lack flavor and taste like American Chinese food rather than authentic Chinese food.
So good. Love the twice cooked pork, green beans, mapo tofu, etc. Everything is delicious. Coming from a person whose mom is from Szechuan!

I have been going to Han Dynasty since it opened in University City years ago. It is my favorite Chinese restaurant. Best Szechuan in the country. I have been sharing my love for this place since I first had it years ago. However, I felt it was time to make a post about it on Yelp so I could let as many people as possible know why I love this place. The hot tea in the beginning gets your appetite ready for the amazing meal thats to come. They do not waste your time in taking your order or getting the food out to you. It is so efficient and consistent. I have never had a bad experience at Han. The Dan Dan Noodles and double cooked chicken are my favorite things on the menu. You have to try those if you go. If you like spicy food and are feeling adventurous, I would recommend taking it up to at least a spice level 7 to really enjoy it. They got lots of space so feel free to bring a big party. I promise once you have their Dan Dan noodles, you won't like them at any other restaurant.

I've been here a bunch of times because in general everyone loves it.  And I must say I always get the cucumbers and the DanDan noodles because they are awesome.  But I've never really loved any entree I have ordered here.  Until this week.  I found out I was just ordering the wrong thing.  This time we ordered a long hot pepper style w pork.  And garlic sauce style w lamb.  Both were excellent w the garlic sauce style w lamb being my favorite.

I finally made it!  First, sadly, I have the unfortunate responsibility of making those of you who weren't aware that the generous Yelp offer of free spicy crispy cucumbers (default spice level of 6) is no longer available.  That didn't dissuade me from ordering it; glad I did because they were very tasty.  The spice was significant but I could've handled a 7 or possibly even an 8.  

Of course, I had the dan dan noodles as well.  There's nothing I can add to what other Yelpers have said other than it's a definite "must get".  This comes with a default spice level of 7 but, just as with the cucumbers, I could've stood even more.

Silly me, dining solo I was unaware of the portion size so my initial thought to follow those orders with an entree went straight out the window.  But there's always next time.

Taking full advantage of the Happy Hour prices, a Victory pale ale draft was a great choice as its crispness paired awesomely with the spice of the food.  Water refills were thankfully abundant.

Service was near perfect.  My server explained the spice scale but not at all snootily and my food came out within five minutes.  He mentioned that a 2 is on par with Tabasco sauce which I thought is a great way to educate customers prior to ordering.

That recaps my first visit.  Having dined at Han Dynasty I can now say I feel complete.

Finally tried the Dan Dan noodles that everyone is raving about and I will have to go against the majority.  While I understand the appeal of the dish, it was just too heavy and greasy for me. 

We also ordered the Crispy Rice Style with Pork.  I really liked the sauce with the dish but was hoping for more of the crispy rice.  I'm guessing we had the lunch portion, which was a decent portion to split but came with two small rice cake like discs.

It's so close to my work so I will have to try more items from the menu.

Han Dynasty ("handy nasty," as affectionately called among Penn students) reliably provides a superb culinary and social experience. It's my go-to campus restaurant for special occasions like birthdays and graduations. The tasting menu has affordable options for a large group (around $25, there are choices based on the types of meat you want to order). They bring out a TON of food and there are always many leftovers, but in the process you get to try out so many of Han's unique offerings (including tripe and rabbit stew!). 

I also have a consistently pleasant experience with the service at Han Dynasty. The food comes out very quickly and the waiters are generous with water and tea refills. 

For Han first-timers, here are some of my favorite dishes that I recommend:
- spicy crispy cucumbers
- cumin beef (very spicy!)
- garlic style chicken (milder but very tasty)
- double cooked fish (the waiter told us it's the staff's favorite! very delicious)
- dan dan noodles, of course

This place still has it. Used to go here often back when I was I college and had to stop by while we were in town again. Since we were taking the train out that day, did a small lunch of our favorites:

1. Dan Dan Noodles - always a must get
2. Pork Belly in Sweet Garlic Chili Oil - very garlic forward and complements any spicy entree
3. Dry Pepper Chicken - super crispy w/ aromatic Sichuan peppercorns

The Old City location didn't do lunch so we went here instead. It's takeout for lunch and they had a few tables outside.

I came here on a Sunday evening with one of my best friends. The restaurant was busy, but we got seated without any wait. The host and waiter were pretty friendly. Since neither of us were new to Han Dynasty, we went with our favorite dishes, Dan Dan noodles, Dry pepper style chicken, and string beans with minced pork. The dishes flew out of the kitchen in just about 10-12 minutes, and they all tasted great! I was glad they didn't go too crazy with the salt. This is definitely a great spot to bring visiting friends/family that love spicy/Szechwan food.

Han Dynasty is the sorta old reliable of accessible Sichuan Chinese fare in Philadelphia.  It's frequently delicious, mildly adventurous and easy for groups big and small.  I've returned several times to both this and the Old City location.

The Good:

Delicious Sichuan food with the right amount of spice for anyone (you pick on a scale of 1-10).  The Dan Dan noodles are a personal favorite (any every one else agrees), the Bok Choi is a great add on and I have yet to dislike any entree.

The service is pretty standard.  As I like to say, if you didn't notice it was bad, then it was good.  Also, the food comes somewhere between an ideal pace and fast.  

The Old City location is a bit more enjoyable ambiance than the U City one.  Things are dim, but the decorations and furnishings are nice.  It's slightly less accommodating to large groups, but YMMV.  

I think the prices are pretty reasonable.  Entrees range from 15-20 dollars but are meant for more than one person.  It's hard to say if it's a good deal, but the food is still excellent.

The Bad:

One issue I find is that it's hard to push the issue on spiciness.  I've grown to really enjoy some heat and it's hard to get servers to really let the chef kick it up a notch.  

The other issue is that I often don't feel super great the next day after eating.  Maybe that's the spices or my amateur palate or the several cocktails I had.  

Conclusion:  I return because it's reliable and delicious.  I will continue to return.  Just keep a bottle of pepto in your cabinet.

Every time I eat there, I constantly find myself wondering why I don't go back more often. First off, get the punch bowl if you're of age. It's awesome to share, it's fun, it's got some strength to the alcohol, and it's delish. But mostly just fun - comes in a huge bowl and is super colorful with silly straws. 

On top of that, the food is solid solid solid. I love places that have family style eating because I always just think it's more fun that way. It's also kinda fun arguing with friends about what level heat you think the meal should be. But anyway, I think the food is delicious. I've tried almost all their entrees now and have never been disappointed in any of them. I almost always get a fried rice which (shockingly) pairs well with any of the entrees. Oh also. The wonton soup is great - I'd say slightly above your standard wonton soup, which is certainly worth noting. 

Can't speak to authenticity of the Szechuan style of food, but I think it's a great spot. Great ambience, would definitely recommend for a fun type of evening, especially if you get the punch bowl, which seems to be underrated and not spoken about enough in reviews.

I've been to this particular Han Dynasty many times for lunch and dinner and have never left disappointed. The staff is friendly, the service is fast, and the food is generally very good. I made my most recent trip last night and once again left satisfied, though some dishes were better than others.

The standouts: Dan Dan noodles, dry pepper fish, string beans with minced pork, and the tea smoked duck in beer sauce. I don't think I've ever eaten at HD without ordering the first three, and for good reason-- the noodles were perfectly cooked, the fish was well-seasoned, and the string beans were delicious while allowing us to pretend we were being healthy because vegetables = always healthy. None of us had ever ordered the duck before, but it was smoky and tender.

Not bad but not great: Dry pepper chicken and the hot sauce style beef. The dry pepper chicken had good flavor, but was more bread than chicken. The hot sauce beef actually had a good portion of meat, but the flavor was unremarkable.

Avoid: Wontons in chili oil. These were soggy and a bit sour. I only managed to eat half of one (and they were not very big). Definitely the least popular dish at our table.

If you want to experience the family style dining at HD, I'd recommend going for lunch, as the menu is basically the same but significantly cheaper (generally when I've gone for lunch I pay under $20...dinner last night was $33). Also, they can adjust the spice level if you don't like spicy food, though I should mention that everything we ordered yesterday was at least an 8 on the spice-meter but we found nothing spicy (caveat: I'm Nigerian and my 3 dinner mates are Chinese, thus we're all quite used to *very* spicy food...so experiences may vary). All in all, Han Dynasty is great for group dining and you'll never leave hungry.

Absolutely no to Mapo tofu.   I got it without Hunan beans and it still tastes like Hunan beans.  And this dish is just tofu and all chili oil.  It is hands down the worst mapo tofu I have had so far.  But that's just one  dish.

While not as good as Old City, still bomb.

Han Dynasty has been one of my favorite restaurants since freshman year and the Old City location has been a staple place in my diet. When the new one opened up in University City, I was ecstatic because I could now enjoy all the spicy Szechaun goodness anytime, even in my pajamas (still haven't attempted though).

Upon stepping in, you definitely feel like you're in a different place. The interior is a lot more modern, more industrial looking than its sister branch. The servers, with their obnoxious "10" on their backs (representing the spicy scale they use on their menu), are just as attentive, but not as knowledgeable. Our server didn't know if certain dishes were vegetarian or not, or what type of tea they were serving. My friend and I opted for the Cold Chili Oil Noodles and Dry Hot Pot Style Chicken.

The cold noodle is probably one of my favorite dishes in the place. So simple, but so delicious. The combination of red chili oil, minced garlic, and a soy sauce mixture really opened our taste buds and is still on my list of favorites. It was my first time trying their dry hot pot style anything and while it's still not on my list of favorites, it was indeed tasty. The presentation is pretty cool: the dish is served on top of a propane-lit mini-stove at the table. The spiciness level wasn't quite where I like it, but the chicken was very tender and the combination of veggies made for a great pairing with rice (which we of course got seconds of).

Still a fan of Han Dynasty, but I'm pretty picky with food and I'm not sure if this new location steps up to the challenge. Next time I'm looking for a date spot, I might trek down to Old City. But if I'm craving some cold noodle or stopping by for happy hour (their menu/drink specials looked very appealing), the UC location will do just fine.

Pros: location, attentive of service, interior, serves alcohol
Cons: not quite the same as original, new staff

Dishes to try (my overall Han favorites): Cold Chili Oil Noodles, Wontons in Chili Oil, Dry Pepper Style Chicken, Peppercorn Fish Tofu Stew

Can never go wrong here- a few favorites are the kung pao chicken extra spicy, spicy wontons, and dan dan noodles. The lunch specials on uber eats are a great deal if you work in the area! Preparation is fast/on time as predicted.

Not sure if it was because I was extra hungry today, or if the kitchen staff was extra awesome today, but the food today was ON POINT! 

We ordered dan-dan noodles, dry pepper chicken, kung pow chicken, garlic beef and dumplings. There were 4 of us and we all ate enough to feel full. 

Service was super quick (even better because we were SO hungry) and helpful. No complaints today! Great food and great time with friends.

Han dynasty is one of my favorite Asian restaurants in Philly. All their dishes taste great and I especially enjoy getting the Dan Dan noodles, the dry pot dishes, and their spicy hot pot. Their hot pot is about 25 dollars but is large enough to share between two people. It's not like the traditional shabu shabu where you cook your own food because it's all cooked for you and ready to eat, but the soup base is delicious! It tastes authentic and they use a lot of different spices. Plus, there's a lot of fish, scallops, shrimps, and beef slices in the soup. On a cold day, this is my go to dish. When I first visited Han dynasty I thought the food was going to be more Americanized because of the modern ambience, but they actually taste like what I'd eat at an authentic Asian hole in the wall, except much cleaner and a bit more pricey. For the quality of the food and the great atmosphere, this place is top notch.

I go to Han Dynasty so often that it might as well be an addiction. I have tried every single item on that menu at least once. If you don't like Han Dynasty, it is because some ridiculous childhood trauma has rendered you soulless and dead inside.

You can be assured that every dish I mention in this review is a favorite. Here's how to do Han Dynasty right, based on countless experiences with varying numbers of people at this restaurant-

"The Lonely Man"(for one lonely, sad person)
Dan Dan Noodles, dumplings in chili oil. You will have leftovers.

"The Basic"(for two people, probably a date early in the relationship)
Dan Dan Noodles, Spicy Cucumber, Three Cup Chicken - You will have leftovers.

"Company"(for three people, because your significant other has someone visiting from out of town and you want them to like you)
Dan Dan Noodles, Spicy Cucumber, Double cooked pork belly, Fried Taiwanese sausage.

"The Party"(for four people, because three folks from your work are tired of hearing about you rave about the restaurant and have demanded that you take them.)
Dan Dan Noodles, Spicy Cucumber, Dry Pepper Shrimp, Fish hot pot

Any party greater than 4 usually means that someone with Han Dynasty experience will be in the party and should know what the hell they are doing.

The U.City location is larger and serves the food more quickly than any other location. Seriously, they are really fast here. I've eaten here and received my Dan Dan noodles and cucumbers before the drinks arrive. It is ridiculous.

I've given so many stars to Han's restaurants on Yelp that this chain might as well be its own group of constellations. Google "han dynasty rap" for more of my shameless plugging of this restaurant.

We love Han Dynasty and have ordered take out fairly regularly during the pandemic. We love it so much that it was our Christmas Eve takeout meal. There are no pictures because we inhaled it all as soon as we opened the containers.

Started with scallion pancakes. Honestly, I was never about ordering them as a takeout appetizer and I was right. They don't travel well. Not a fault of Han, but just a fact.

We split an order of Dan Dan Noodles. They are an always order often added without asking the other person. 

I ordered the Chicken Dry Pepper Style entree . It's a heat level 8 so it's hot, but I like that. My boyfriend ordered the Beef Garlic Sauce Style which is a heat level 3 (perfect for him!)

We are thankful that Han Dynasty was open on Christmas Eve and appreciate all of their hard working employees!

This is one of my favorite places to eat in University City and I've been here multiple times with my friends. Each time we've come here, our meal has been around $15-$20 per person which is definitely worth it for how good the food is and how full we leave. 

Dishes we got this time:
Eggplant with garlic sauce: so much flavor in the sauce and very meaty, really enjoyed eating it with rice. 
Three cup chicken: Everyone's favorite--a sweet and salty flavor, would recommend this above everything else. 
Wontons in chili oil: Not a huge fan of this, probably wouldn't get it again because it was a bit sour and I like chili oil wontons to be more sweet and spicy. 
Dry pot chicken and hot sauce style chicken: Honestly not a huge fan of this either but I'm just not inclined toward super spicy things in general. My friends liked it though. 
Scallion pancakes: I liked it better last time we ordered because this time it was very oily so this dish seems to be hit or miss. 


Overall, food is amazing. The service can be a bit slow and it took a while for our food to come out.

Let's see....

Spicy cucumber is the best.  I am absolutely crazy about it.  I made the mistake of taking some home as left overs just so I can have more later... but that was a bad idea.  The cucumbers for soft and it shriveled up. Spicy cucumber is definitely something you  should just indulge in and not look back.  I LOVE the sauce.  Sometimes I have cucumbers lying around, so when I get it as a take out and have left over sauce, I just chop up some more and toss it in.  The sauce is so delectable.  Also, I love using the spicy cucumber sauce as dipping sauce for the scallion pancakes.  

I also enjoy the spicy beef noodle soup.  The broth is light, and is great for the winter time.

Dan-dan noodles is a must.  Short and sweet - it's a must.

The mapo tofu was only okay - but it's most likely because I can't stand Hunan beans.  If you don't like Hunan beans either, try asking if it's possible to make it without.  

I didn't really like the salt-pepper squid.  The squid was a bit mushy in texture - which was strange to me.  There's nothing wrong with the flavor, but the texture freaked me out.  Just the texture..

Every time I have been here the service has been great.  Everyone is so nice and friendly, helpful, and attentive.

I always have a good time and a good meal here. It's one of those places I come when I can't really figure out what to eat, but I know that I want something delicious, and am too famished to spend much time thinking about it. The food is always great and the drinks are pretty good also. I've always sat at the bar here, because it's usually pretty packed. My favorite dishes are the ones with lamb. Make sure to pay attention to the numbers listed in parentheses following each dish. They really DO indicate spiciness. Service has always been on point also. This is definitely my preferred location of this chain.

09/12/21;
Came here as the ppl I'm meeting chose the place. But also prob the best Chinese food I had so far in Philly.  (Considering the fact that I haven't had it for a long time here)

the wonton in chili oil  is the first thing came to the table and the smell implies its legitimacy! Hot and spicy! 辣椒油的香气太正宗
Like the dry pot tofu the most, very crispy and with a lot of veggies in it.
Dry pepper chicken and hot sauce beef are okay-- not that legit but taste nice!

The first time I had Han Dynasty was pre-Covid years ago and the food was really great. Last night we ordered takeout via Grubhub and it was ready for pickup in 10 minutes. So a star or 2 for being ready so fast! 

We ordered Dan Dan noodles, Chicken Dumplings,  House Special Fried Rice and Spring Rolls. 

Dan Dan and House Special Fried Rice are always winners for me. They have the only Fried rice that doesn't require you to douse it in soy sauce. So good and flavorful! Now those spring rolls? I'll pass on buying those again. They were super small. I mean they could fit in a kid's hand and bland. Not worth the $5 price tag..Nor were the Dumplings. The small box had 4 dumplings for $8 and just weren't very good.  

I won't count them out but the experience of dining in here is just so much better. Food tends to lose its luster once its thrown into takeout containers. Sigh.

Seating ended much earlier than the end time of the restaurant so we took it to go. So I was told that the Dan Dan Noodles were something I had to try. I am not usually a fan of Dan Dan noodles but the kick on this one was great. Mix it a little with the white rice and you can mellow out the heat a little. The salt and pepper shrimp was good albeit portion was a little small for its dinner price. The scallion pancakes and the dip was great! I had the bok choy and the black mushrooms as well. Great flavor and texture.

I come here weekly and it's definitely one of my favorite Chinese places on campus! They indicate spice level by using numbers from 1-10 on the menu. The higher the number, the spicier it is! I typically get the lunch specials but this time I ate a little late and I got the normal portion- it's so much! There's two of us and the portion is more than enough! We finished the kung pao chicken (it's my favorite) and had leftovers that I brought back. I highly recommend getting the normal portion if you're eating with a large group! Service is also pretty quick and you can refill as much as rice when you dine in. They are also very accommodating as the serve you both iced water and hot tea (which I prefer).

I must say that my experience with this location involved a DoorDash order to the eastern part of Delaware County. And this food is just a different experience for takeout or delivery as opposed to dining in. 

But that's life during Covid. Cant hold that against them. 

What I can say is that despite the travel to get to my house, the Dan Dan Noodles are still a flavor explosion. The dumplings in chili oil are addicting. And the garlic beef still packed quite the punch.

I love ordering from this place. I have ordered a few times from here on Doordash and food comes so fast!! We always get the dan dan noodles and cold sesame noodles. My fiance does not eat pork so I ask for the pork on the side for the noodles and they always accommodate! We always get the garlic sauce with chicken and thats always delicious and has a sweetness to it. We always get so much food that we have enough for dinner the next day. The food is spicy and I can handle spice so i learned I have to ask them to come down a notch on the spice levels. Will definitely be ordering from here again!

Orders can be delivered through caviar. Don't order dandan noodles for delivery unless sauce is kept separate from noodle. It was horrible as a delivery item; not representative of actual dish. We love the Garlic Sauce Shrimp spice level 4(definitely do-able). Also their dumplings and vegetable spring rolls are Very tasty. Nothing beats going in person to enjoy their dishes though. I prefer old city location, much bigger and impressive.

I've never been inside this location of Han Dynasty, but when we order takeout from HD, we get it from here. 

There is enough salt in the food to make you bloated for days, but that won't stop the occasional intense craving that must be satiated. Our go-to starters are always the same: spicy cucumbers and dan dan noodles. Sometimes we'll throw in the scallion pancakes. 

My man always gets some sort of dry/hot pepper chicken thing which is very good but loaded with hot ass peppers. My mouth is always on fire enough as-is from the appetizers, so I go with the much milder garlic shrimp. I like the peppers and onions that are mixed in - they give a nice crunch. 

Until next time, HandyNasty!

I have given this location more chances than I should.  Yet, each time they find a way be non-worthy.  My recent dine in here was with a friend.   We waited for about 10 minutes before any one showed.  Blah.  So we ordered.  My food comes out.  Another 10 minutes or so goes by and the server notices my friend's food did not.  Meanwhile, my food got cold from waiting for these numbskulls to get her food out.  The server goes to my friend, "Do you still want it?" HA!  

Let's see... Not having pea leaves but still keeping it in the menu? Lame.  Update it.  It's been half a mfking year. White it out.  Cross it out.  Put a sticker over it.   

I also asked on a separate occasion to have a sauce substitute.  They said no NOT because it was pre-made, but because they said the chef doesn't feel like it.   The chef doesn't want to "ruin the integrity" of the dish.  Bitch please!  Don't ever imply that I have poor taste.

House special lo mein, double cooked fish,  garlic style wings,  string beans with pork topped with rice and tea made for a lovely lunch today with my family. 

This place was packed at lunch today,  we had a little bit of a wait but it was worth it.  Fast service, quality food and lively atmosphere.   There was even Christmas music playing in the background. 

Nice outing,  Han never disappoints.

I dined at Han Dynasty without knowing what kind of food it served and how it was so well received by the Yelp community. Without knowing much about the restaurant, I was practically dragged here against my will. I'm sure you can only imagine my surprise and delight once I found out this was not an Americanized-Chinese take-out restaurant. I mean, one assumes the worst when it's near college campus, right?

My friends did the ordering. I didn't know it at the time, but they ordered the dishes that every Yelper raves about. Among the dishes we ordered, I absolutely loved the Spicy Crispy Cucumber! I could not stop eating them. When our waiter brought it over, they didn't particularly look special, but boy, was I wrong. The sweet and spicy sauce was so addictive - I poured some over the rice and ate it together too (so good!)

While the food was amazing, the service was not as impressive. Everything was very rushed. The moment we were seated, our waiter walked over and asked about our drink order. Obviously, we had to ask him to come back in a couple of minutes because none of us had a chance to look at their drink menu. Similar things happened when we were done with certain dishes/plates. Our waiter was really keen on taking the finished dishes away from our table.. except they weren't completely done. Like when he took my cucumber dish away - yes, I did eat all the cucumbers, but I still needed the sauce! The least he could have done was ask! He didn't even ask beforehand whether he can take it away. So yeah, I died a little inside as I saw my beloved cucumber dish being taken away.. :( but I'll be back for more!

Ordered here a few weeks back. If you go through Grubhub, give them your first name when you go to pick up. It took about 35 minutes or so during early evening.

On to the food:

Dan Dan Noodles
Top notch as always. Peanutty with slight burn, we got them mild.

Wontons in Chili Oil
A slight disappointment. Kind of a sour taste to the sauce, which was kind of mushy. 

Walnut Shrimp
Packaged separately to avoid transit issues - separate containers for shrimp, sauce and walnuts. A nice touch. As for the shrimp, they were huge but tough and overcooked. Sauce was tasty. 

Smoked tofu with shredded pork
Excellent as usual with hints of garlic in the sauce. 

HomeStyle Tofu
Really good with a terrific sauce and delicious mushrooms. 

Covid-19 precautions:
No dine-in when I was there, only one person at a time for pick-up. Masks required.

This place is amazing, my favorite Chinese restaurant, plus always a great beer selection from around the country but always with some philly classics mixed in - what is not to like.

Oh and by the way the people giving it a low rating because it was too spicy deserve to be stoned to death in the back alley. I'm tired of having the authentic taste of food ruined by the lowest common denominators of society. The last thing we need is authentic szechuan cuisine being ruined by Karen's from Malvern.
Terrible experience. Food was not bad. But service was terrible. Took 1 hour and not even a single entree was ready. Asked waiter to check for so many times. Automatically applied 20% tips.

Nice place with plenty of seating in University City. I have been to the locations in Center City and out by King of Prussia. This location keeps up with the high standard of delicious food and I would definitely recommend it.

Watch out for the spice level if you are sensitive to it. I would not recommend anything higher than a 4.

Horrendous experience. This place offers a delivery for $4 and after 2+ hours, I still never received my food. Abominable communication between driver and the restaurant, and between Han Dynasty and customers. The woman at the restaurant tried to make it seem like it wasn't their fault that delivery wasn't on time. When I wanted to cancel the order, they even tried to give me a difficult time. Didn't even apologize. Obviously do not value customer service.

The service here was a lot better than any other Han Dynasty that I've been to so kudos for that. 
The food there was on par to every other Han Dynasty I went to. I thought that their dishes had a bit too much oil in them however, it practically dripped of grease. 
We had the spicy beef noodle soup which was just a vat of orange reddish colored oil and spice.  I was a bit put off by the oil but everyone else liked the dish and all of it. 
We also had the dry pepper style chicken which is always my favorite dish! It was prepared really well where the outside was perfectly crisp leaving the inside tender and juicy. Needless to say, we finished that dish first. 
I was between getting the garlic style eggplant or the garlic style tofu and since I already had the eggplant (which is amazing) I opted for the tofu. The dish itself was good but compared to the eggplant it paled in comparison.

BEST NOODLES IN UNIVERSITY CITY. 

My favorite menu item here is the Dan Dan noodles. A must eat! I also love the eggplant dish and the cold cucumber. I will say the scallion pancakes are mediocre, nothing special, but I still get them. This is a great place for large groups and family style meals. I've also put in catering orders and have had great experience with that.

The takeout was not great. I ordered black mushrooms with baby bokchoy. It had a nice tasty sauce but the vegetable was way too sandy. Looks like someone forgot to wash the veggies. The fried fish with leeks and chili oil was rather tasteless. The batter was way too thick and over powered tge fish. . The chicken in garlic sauce had a mild vinegary, sweet and salty taste, but someone forgot to put in the bell peppers.

I dont know what happened. I dined here before covid and it was great.

I don't think I could have had a better experience on my first trip to Han Dynasty. I've been trying to try the place out for years, but I somehow would always end up going somewhere else.

We walked in on a Friday without a reservation. The hostess apologized and said I may have to wait a whole 15 minutes. I decided to tough it out. Eventually, a spot at the bar opened up so the nightmare ended. A fellow bar fly was super talkative and started recommending dishes. We took his advice and started with dumplings and spicy cucumbers. They were great. The spicy levels on the menu are really helpful. For entrees, we went with the cumin style lamb and a chicken dish off of the specials menu. I hadn't seen lamb on a Chinese menu before, and I was really impressed by how well they cooked it.

At some point the owner wandered behind the bar and struck up a conversation. He was a really personable guy, and that alone would make me want to come back... also to try everything else on the menu.

Ordered Chicken Lo Mein from here. Very well made, lots of chicken. This is a full restaurant which I didn't know since I literally just Google mapped nearest Chinese takeout while on the highway. It was kind of expensive for takeout. Two orders of lo mein set us back $23. We were in a jam so it worked but just beware of cost. Would love to check out fuller menu and dine in.

Went there on Sunday night at 8:30 & I have been told by waiter that kitchen already closed at 7ish... I'm tired to argue with waiter even Han official website shows Sunday open until 10pm. Discrimination to POC from ... you know

This place has gotten better over the years. I came here on a very busy weekend but was seated quickly in their new extension dining area. The staff was very attentive and food was great as usual. 

This time, my favorite dish was the Dan San Noodles. They tasted great, had a bit of spice, and the peanut sauce flavoring was one of the best I've ever had. Highly, highly recommend it. I had a great time overall and enjoyed every dish.

My favorite Han in Philly. The food is so tasty, it comes out very quick and the spice level is true to what you expect when you tell them what level you want. My personal favorite cold small dish is the spicy cucumbers; I could eat that all day - the sauce is so good. Dan dan noodles are always great at this location. I've tried them at the Old City and Manayunk locations but the ones here are better. There's not one thing that I've tried that I don't like here. Some dishes we get regularly: garlic style chicken, kung pao chicken, cumin tofu/chicken, dry pepper style, 3 cup chicken, dumplings, friends have said the wontons are great. Highly recommend 10/10.
